content:
ber 27, 2016
												Short and sweet:A little bit of something for everyone. Pros-Impressive enemy numbers on screen-Guns and melee feel good each in their own right-Skilltree helps you determine differing playstyles for players (stealth, crafting, combat)-Night time presents on overarching emphasis of urgency in gameplay-Hardcore players are rewarded extra exp for night time progress-Combat is difficult which makes each encounter very tense-Players can opt out of combat by focusing on movement-Movement, attacks and manuevers all mesh very well-Lots of creative set pieces-Altitude feels apparent-Graphics and style are above average -Entirely soloable without feeling like the game was meant for more players (Same devs as Dead Island so I figured it was worth mentioning)-Coop (Never tried)-Play as Zombie (Never tried)-30+ hours of content (You don't get bang for your buck like this anymore) I got impatient in the later half the game and started doing only main missions-Satisfying story ending (So many games get this wrong I'm glad I can feel some closure in finishing a story)Cons-Combat is unforgiving and some setpieces have infinitely spawning enemies, game makes no indication to tell you when this happens-UI is designed with consoles in mind-Crafting is a pain when you want the benefits of buffs but don't want to hassle with the crafting menu or searching for resources all the time-Story often falls flat and it's often difficult to care too much about the characters since they're mostly one dimensional and very predictable.-Dying is easy if you don't take the game seriously, and if you die too much you will lose levels which are slow to rise.This creates a good sense of tension but also means you can't experiment or mess around for fun without worrying about how much progress you could lose.Neutral/Opinion-Game is really creepy/scary at some portions, especially indoor sections where you get confined to a small area and get mobbed by zombies (this happens a lot and I was getting sick of it). In singleplayer this can start feeling very clausterphobic when you're surrounded and run out of stamina and are swinging for dear life. Consider more research if you think you might get spooked. Not the scariest game out there but it certainly manages to leave an impression.In ClosingHonestly a couple design choices that don't jive with me as a player but the overall game is an easy 8.5 if not higher. Everything from mechanics, design, music is about as spot on as is it could be. Really think theres a bit of something for everybody here. If anyone is too scared to play the game alone they can just open up their lobby too.Thanks for the great game Techland, hope to see more of this from you guys.

content:
ry 13, 2016
												There is one word that best descibes Dying Light:  density.  Dying Light takes everything great from Dead Island and massively improves on it.At first glance, upon being let loose in the sandbox that is Dying Light, you may think the map is small.  I know that was my first impression.  As you explore the city and further the story, you find out just how large the map truly is.  About halfway through the main story line, you will open up another large city area.  The word density truly takes on meaning when you begin exploring this location.  The game opens up more and more locations, including challenge areas (sort of like dungeons in Skyrim) as the game progresses.  Interior locations are numerous, almost mind boggling at times, especially in Old Town.  There are sewers to explore as well.  Transition areas and hidden caverns also help to increase exploration time.  Old Town is really 3 maps stacked on top of each other as there are layers and layers of places to explore.  The Following expansion provides another area to explore, even larger than the main game.And explore you shall.  If you played Dead Island you remember how many times you had to loot that hard shell suitcase, which came in different colors to "spice things up." This became incredibly stale as your eyes became used to scanning for that same container, among just a few others.  With Dying Light, looting shouldn't get too stale as the game presents more and more "containers" for you to loot, such as cupboards, trash cans, crates, locked boxes, medicine cabinets, dressers, and of course the bodies of those you slay.  The game will despawn bodies after a while but will drop a "loot package" on the ground for you to loot when you feel safe enough to do so.Loot is numerous and the amount of melee weapons you can wield is staggering.  Just like Dead Island you can modify your weapons by attaching enhancements which increase power, stability, and or durability, as well as, elemental effects.  Speaking of durability, at first you will be annoyed with this.  I know I was.  But after a while, as you find a greater variety of weapons such as rifles and pistols, you won't have to repair nearly as many times as you did at first as your arsenal will grow.  Each melee weapon has a limited amount of durability, then it breaks.  But again, you won't grow too attached to weapons as you'll have an infinite supply of them waiting to be looted or crafted.  Yes, you can craft weapons and some of the best ones are hidden throughout the world as blueprints.  Dying Light has quite a few easter eggs and hidden locations for you to find, adding even more density to an already deep game.Gunplay is also great in Dying Light, a big improvement over Dead Island.  The rifles sound "meaty." I highly recommend completing Bozak's Horde though.  It's a challenge where, once completed, you receive blueprints to Bozak's Bow.  This bow is great and is better than the ones added in The Following expansion.   You can craft or buy arrows for it and you can retrieve your arrows most of the time after firing them.  Any game with bows as a weapon has my interest right off.The best way to describe what you can do in Dying Light is to compare it to GTA V.  There are so many things to do you will often get distracted and forget what you started out for.  Air drops add another layer of fun as they seem to entice you to put on hold your current task to get to them first.  I remember that at one point I was trying to sneak into an area at night, attempting to avoid nightstalkers, and an air drop was initiated not too far from me.  But in Dying Light, nights are dark, and I kept arguing with myself over whether or not going for the air drop was smart.  I decided to take off running for it and alerted the nightstalkers around me by accident.  I was almost there, I could see the airdrop.  Almost there...I popped flairs around the air drop and the nightstalkers paused for a moment, screaming and clawing at the air.  I hastily popped open the drop and looted it.  The flair went out and the nightstalkers closed in and ripped me to shreds.  Ah well.  Maybe next time.  These are the kinds of moments Dying Light can provide.  Tense, rewarding, and at times dangerous.I won't spend much time discussing the parkour element of the game as that's well known to everyone thinking about buying it.  Let's just say that the parkour/player movement in this game is leaps and bounds (pun intended) better than ANY game in its genre.  Movement is fluid once you get used to it.  Add a grappling hook, which you get later on, and I'm sold...the movement and freedom in this game is liberating and will make it hard to go back to any open world game that restricts your movement.I found the characters to be as interesting as they could be, considering the "zombie apocolypse character archetype" has been used to death (pun intended) with the vast amount of zombie games out there.  But, I remember all the main characters as they are engaging and sometimes funny enough to be remembered.  Many other reviwers have commented that the characters and story are boring.  I haven't found them to be so at all.  The voice acting is well done and varied enough to keep you engaged.  As you explore the city, you'll encounter survivors that are there saveable but some that are just waiting to tell you their story, adding to the lore of the game.  It's touches like this that make a world feel as engaging as this one does.I have yet to finish the story as I am having so much fun playing in this sandbox.  Perhaps I never will finish the story.  If that becomes the case, I won't feel cheated at all because it will have been my choice to just roam, kill zeds, loot, and explore to my heart's content.Zombies are not difficult by themeselves.  But, Dying Light's dense environments provide so many spots for zombies to hide that you can't ever get too comfortable.  Loot that extra box at your peril.  Killing zeds is extremely satisfying.  Sometimes I find myself snapping out of a 30 minute 'kill fest" where I swear I was in a Kill Bill scene.  Speaking of Kill Bill, you can use a katana in Dying Light!Overall, I can truthfully say that Dying Light, plus its recent expansion called The Following, has and will continue to provide more return for my money than the last 5 games I've bought on Steam.  The possibilities with this game are endless and when you add seamless multiplayer/coop to this discussion, you can see why Dying Light is worth the asking price if you like zombie or open world, "do whatever you want" type games.  If you're a gamer that likes to take your time, explore, loot, get distracted, etc. then I wouldn't be surprised if it provides you with 500+ hours of play time.  I highly recommend this game and the season pass which includes all DLC.10/10

Its just Dead Island done right To all casual gamers surely buy this game and ask your buddy to do the same cause its most enjoyable in COOP Overall Rating 9/10Good Night Good Luck  😎

content:
2015
												Decided to change my review to a more serious one, because why not.Pros:-The resilience of the zombies: I distinctly remember setting a zombie on fire with a fire weapon. It was still walking around so I decided to cut it's head off. (It was technically dead by this point) It was still walking around after that so I decided to cut it in half. The torso was still on fire and walking around so I decided to cut the legs off. It wiggled around for a few more seconds and then finally died. So much for putting things out of their misery.-The side quests: They can be very fun to play, but they actually have some good  twists in their own story, and they sometimes foreshadow what is going to happen next in the main story quests-The atmosphere: Harran feels very much like a dead city. Flaming cars, occasional screams, hordes of zombies everywhere, and even dead silence-Mods: One of the few AAA games I can think of that actively encourages modding of the game. There's already a lot of custom maps for the game in the Steam Workshop, including a couple that parallel Techland's work in terms of quality, and there's the possibility for other kinds of mods further down the line (ex. new weapons, blueprints)-Night time: Techland isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around when they say "Good night, good luck". The game changes from a zombie slasher to full-on horror once the lights go out. Predators called Volatiles come out only at night, they are nearly impossible to kill, are very fast, and can often kill you with a single hit.-Hard mode: Some people complain that the game becomes too easy towards the ending half, this fixes that. "Survivor sense" is limited to seeing Volatiles through walls at night, normal zombies become much more damaging (killing in just 2-3 hits), medikits do not regen your health instantly, and certain items become harder to find. This mode addresses most of the issues I list in the "contriversial" section-Game looks pretty good graphically: Very good textures, amazing foliage, and nicely detailed weapons. Apparently the lighting is based on physics, I don't know what that means but it looks beautiful-Pack mentality of the zombies: If you kill one zombie, there will probably be two or three more that come around a corner and try to eat you-Uniquely balanced firearms: Sure, you can use a pistol to kill that zombie, but there will be a group of Virals (fast zombies) that will come for you almost immediately-Surprisingly tactical melee combat especially when facing other survivors: The enemy survivors are very, very smart. They can block your hits, dodge them, kick you, dodge your kicks, throw knives at you, and knock the knives you throw at them out of the air (but you can do all of that, too). This requires you to time your attacks well since they can beat you to death very easily if you only try to attack-The physics in the game are amazing: For some reason Techland decided to add actual weight and momentum to your player. This means you can jump from the roof of a van, land on a zombie, and you will crush it under your own weight, leaving it's head vulnerable so you can beat it in with a gas pipe. Also, you can dropkick a zombie into a car, and if it hits headfirst, it will die.-The map design: Techland has designed certain subtle paths for parkour you can take, which flow very naturallyControversial (aka some people hate it, some like it):-The way the weapons hit enemies: It seems like Techland decided to treat the weapon in your hand as an actual physical object with weight and force. This means that all weapons in the game feel REALLY, REALLY GOOD. A blunt weapon will likely stop in it's place when it hits an enemy, which feels realistic and pretty brutal when you're trying to bash a zombie's head in when it's laying on the ground. If the game triggers slow motion, you can sweep the camera around, and hit other zombies in that sweep without touching the mouse button. However, this has a bad side effect - if you have a weak weapon like a pipe and there's an enemy standing to the right of an enemy you want to hit, the weapon will likely bounce off of the enemy on the right and will not touch the enemy you want to hit, which can be very frustrating.-The parkour system: People have praised the parkour system as the best of the new generation so far. However, I feel like there are some problems with it very similar to the problems that most parkour systems have, like things you should be able to grab onto, but can't. Trying to grab onto something below you is a HUGE pain in the ♥♥♥, usually it ends up with you flying off, then mashing the spacebar trying to grab on again. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. Usually you don't end up where you wanted to go. However, in just about every other movement, it feels pretty natural and flows nicely.-The damage the weapons do towards the end of the game: You start the game off with a pipe for a weapon. It does 24 damage. You will likely end the game with a katana/machete/longsword/shotgun. These things do upwards of 1000 damage. The enemies' health do not scale to the weapons you have, so, you can just slice through hundreds of infected with no problem, and can even kill Volatiles with just a few hits. However, this doesn't compromise the way the weapons feel. Somehow, the weapons still stay incredibly satisfying throughout the entire game.-The plot: The antagonist is pretty cliche, he's someone from the Middle East who is terrorizing the people of Harran during the infection. The guy you play is pretty cliche as well, he's an American who just happens to be really good at parkour as well as killing zombies, even though he's never done either of those things before. However, outside the rivalry, the plot does take some interesting twists and turns, questioning the morality of the "greater good" and whether or not Rais (the antagonist) is really your enemy.Cons:-The motion blur is overused: It looks like Techland decided to put motion blur on literally everything. This makes it very hard to appreciate the graphical beauty of the game with it on.-Some enemies are almost impossible to kill without taking damage: There's a strong enemy with a giant piece of rebar in the game. His main attack is hitting the rebar on the ground, which creates a shockwave that takes away most of your health. 30% of the way through the game, the size of that shockwave doubles. Before, you could easily dodge out of the way, now, it is close to impossible.-The controls for throwing/grappling an enemy are very awkward: Alt & W/A/S/D at the same time. I'll let you try that one.

content:
y 30, 2015
												After 100+ hours on this game, I feel I have played enough to write a solid review. I preordered this game about 3 months prior to release and was able to play the game on day 1. After watching trailers and gameplay I was super hyped for this game (I am a huge zombies fan in general).  On day 1 as you can probably imagine the game had some optimization issues and ran very poorly for all the people using AMD hardware. These issues were resolved about 3 weeks later and as of right now this game runs very smoothly and consistently if you have a GTX 960 or higher. Visually this game looks amazing and the developers did a fantastic job with the graphics (the Chrome Engine 6 is stunningly beautiful if your hardware can drive it), something I always appreciate being a graphics fanatic. I played around 60 hours in the month of January, finished the game, and absolutley loved it. Not every game keeps me interested from start to finish the way this game did. Now for those of you wanting a comparison between this game and Dead Island. This game is a HUGE improvement. The 4 player co-op is perfectly done and actually allows you to play through every mission (INCLUDING THE MAIN STORY), together with your friends. Another awesome addition is the Terrifying Day/Night cycle where the deadly volatiles come out and make even the best weapons seem like plastic. At some point you will find yourself outside as the sun goes down and the city becomes completely dark. then all you are left with is your flashlight and however far you have to run to get to a safehouse. The thrill of getting chased by Volatiles in the dark while running for your life is quite exhilarating. If you are looking for the best co-op zombie game to play with your friends, this is it, Period. Although the storyline is quite predictable and ends with a somewhat displeasing boss fight at the end; it is pretty irrelevant in the grand scheme of this game, the game has Tons of other side quests for you to complete, most are rewarding and enable you to get some kick *** weapon upgrade or blueprint. The game is extrememely fun to just mess around in and have fun with your friends and there are many easter eggs and craftable items which enable you to keep making your character more and more OP and awesome. After 60 hours in January I have recently Racked up another 40 in the past 2 weeks after I found out about all the blueprints and easter eggs there are to complete (all 40 hours spent playing with friends and people I met playing Dying Light). I must take a quick moment to mention how gratifying it is for me to kill a zombie in this game. Not even Dead Island has as good animations as this game does for executing zombies. I can literally drop kick a zombie to the ground, run at it, cut its arms off, throw a knife in its head, cut its head off, knock it to the ground again, cut its arms and legs off, kick the body away leaving the body parts scattered 10 feet from each other, and then burn the remains. Now that might have sounded gory to some of you...but for those of you sick of playing COD zombies and only being able to shoot a zombie in the head...well..you can probably guess why killing zombies in this game is Nothing short of amazing.Lastly I have to mention the Parkour and open world of this game. I have never played a game with such a fun parkour system as this. I can literally entertain myself for hours just having races from one side of the city to the other with friends; Jumping over rooftops and getting creeped by those moments when your "Not sure if your gonna be able to make the jump to the other building". The parkour system in this game is designed perfectly and surprisingly I can say that I have never encountered any glitches when jumping around and climbing walls where I fall unexpectedly.Bottom line, it's the best zombie game out there and the best game of the year for me. It will be interesting to see how Dead Island 2 compares to this game when its released.

content:
ry 1, 2015
												EDIT: I have played this game on PS4 for 20+ hours prior to this review. Dying Light is a breath of fresh air, in this landfill of games that copy one another. If you enjoyed the likes of Dead Island, or similar games, you will be right at home with this game, but be wary, there are major differences between the two. The parkour mechanics are very reminiscent of EA's 2008 cult classic, Mirror's Edge. The combat system can be clunky at times, and it is easy to get flustered especially in the early hours of the game; Upgrading weapons is highly recomended if you plan to survive in the late game. Now to talk about what makes this game special. The day and night cycle. During the day, the zombies are your adverage infected that you have seen before, plus a few special infected types.Night time is when things get interesting. A new, fast, and very powerful infected type come out during the dark. Best bet is to always have flares and firecrackers.In conclusion, this game does have a few bugs, but they aren't substantial enough to cause a drop in score. Final verdict: 9/10.   It has been a while since a game has exceeded my expectations on launch day.

I will never understand who thought it would be a good idea to give someone a one-hit-kill attack and an invulnerability shield...Final word.I challenge you to find a zombie on a cliff and not laugh as you dropkick it down the side.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2016
												Dying Light plus The Following (expansion) are what Dead Island and its expansion promised to be but weren't. Techland managed to keep what little good features Dead Island had and improve them by bringing them over to the spiritual successor. Before I go into the endless bashing of Dead Island (the premise is nice but the execution was awful), lets stick to what makes Dying Light a great zombie game.Unlike your run of the mill zombie games, Dying Light regular zombies are not your average slow-moving-arm-flailing-brain-hungry humanoids, wanting nothing more than to land on your bullets or melee weapons. They are scary, they are numerous and they will try to kill you. Their most important quality is numbers however. They'll plentiful and since melee weapons degrade and guns create noise which will attract the improved Virals (think of 28 days later fast zombies) , going into a square with 100 of them is not the best course of action.Dying Light creates a very good atmosphere where you're not just a guns blazing supersoldier going on a bloody rampage against anyone who stands in your way. You're a survivor and you need to survive. That means getting resources, spending them wisely, sleeping the night off or even fight through the night for some extra XP. The game manages to convey the feeling of helplessness into the player in a beautiful tone.There's a variety of special enemies, the most formidable being the so called Volatiles, disfigured monsters of the night who will chase you relentlessly throughout Harran (the city in which the vanilla game takes place).The game's strongpoint is the parkour mechanics. Future games will most likely begin to incorporate this 'new' feature and nothing would be better than game developers taking notes on how Dying Light manages to do freerunning justice. It's super easy to learn, to control, very responsive to your actions, and adds a brilliant way to make perfect use of your environment. I've played game with freerunning mechanics before and nothing comes close to Dying Light's system. Admittedly the grappling hook is a little buggy sometimes, but it's a small price to pay for an otherwise excellent system. Every rooftop, every lamp-post, even corner of a building can be your haven, your battlefield or your grave. Absolutely astounding and it carries over into the Following as well although in a much less degree due to the addition of the buggy.The game features an XP system, in 3 categories (5 with the Enhanced Edition/The Following), which include your fighting skill, your survival and your agility (running&climbing). XP is earned by doing quests (the game features a lot of sidequests with their own mini arcs and characters, ranging from being a little bit on the funny side, to some being just depressing), killing enemies, running and climbing buildings and collecting resources from airdrops. The day/night feature of the game, allows you to get double XP during night, however during night the Volatiles will appears to make your life a living hell. There's a smooth transition between day and night and you will adapt your strategy accordingly.However Dying Light is not without its faults. Guns feel pretty weak and are very limited (vanilla game) however in The Following they were improved dramatically, doing more damage and having more guns to choose from. If you plan on playing Multiplayer co-op with friends, be adviced that the final mission of the game can only be played solo. Why was that a thing? Completely pointless, I mean I can sort of understand due to the reason that the ending of the game falls unfortunately into the dreadful category of QTE(quick time events). Why oh why did you ruin an otherwise good story, with a QTE near the end I'll never understand. And of course, if you're playing with friends, you better disconnect and finish the game on your own, cause the game won't allow you to do it in coop. Big disappointment.The Following is the sequel of the story of the original game. You play in the outskirt farmlands of Harran, where you meet a different set characters. The most important feature is the addition of a the buggy.The buggy feels like a foreign element in the Dying Light world. You do less parkour and use it for transportation since The Following takes place in open rural area with few buildings. There's still plenty of freerunning in The Following, but less than the original game.The Following adds two more extra trees to gain XP in, driving and Legend levels. Driving can be maxed very easily and very quickly just by running enemies over and the Legend levels include passive bonuses on your characters.Don't get me wrong, the Following a pretty solid addition to the game, adds around 20-30 hours of gameplay and it's definitely worth its money.At the same time however, some of the characters feel more shallow than the ones in the vanilla game but the worst offender is the story of the game and its absurd ending. No spoilers but the ending was bad. Like really bad. Mass Effect 3 bad. And of course you cannot finish it in a Multiplayer session with friends. You gotta do it solo. Again...There's no real villain in the Following. The story feels kinda rushed, some things are unexplained or just make no sense within the story of the game and the ending features a deus ex machina which has no real connection to anything you'll encounter in the vanilla game and the expansion.Long story short: Dying Light: The Following - Enhanced Edition is well worth its money and its a definite recommendation for people who feel a little bit of "zombie-game fatigue". It's mechanics are great, it has a pretty decent story (up until the ending of the Following), it looks pretty good, it sounds pretty good, it's very immersive in its atmosphere and you can play it with friends! (up until the final mission). Not without its flaws but the gameplay outshines almost everything.

content:
y 30, 2015
												A joyously fun game with a lot of glaring issues holding it back from true greatness.It brings to the table an exceptionally enjoyable combat system which feels like what Dead Island's combat should have been in the first place, while adding the wonderous addition of parkour elements to the combat and in turn making everything feel much more dynamic, though combat slowly becomes easier over time against normal zombies, but it gets balanced out by ne, stronger special infected. The infected slowly get introduced throughout the story and become part of the open world thereafter. Though combat can become repetitive and frustrating at times, with some enemies taking more hits than they really should.The storyline is very predictable and fairly poorly written, though at the same time oddly charming and engaging in a Resident Evil kinda way. Where while the story is ♥♥♥♥, you still wanna see it through just to find out what horrible line or event will be demonstrated next. Not much else to say here.Quests are decently varied though sometimes a bit repetitive in nature. There are a lot of basic fetch quests, but there's also quite a few scripted story based quests with an interesting layout and areas exclusive to the mission. Side quests feel like other story quests instead of basic small side things. They can become fairly engaging and enjoyable, though yet again may become repetitive. The parkour system is implemnted quite flawlessly and is one of the best elements of the game, it feels silky smooth gliding from building to building, or from zombie to a roof of a far. Some of the most enjoyable parkour elements I've experienced within a game to date.My absolute favorite element of the game is the nighttime though. It turns it into one of the most threatening and intereting experiences within open world games, an experience usually only seen within scripted linear experiences. There's nothing more exhillerating than quietly sneaking past the large infected to get to an air drop, before being seen and having to run like all hell to a safe house from a horde before being taken down and killed. Absolutely wonderous.Visually the game is absolutely gorgeous. Wonderful lighting, wonderful shading, wonderful models, wonderful animations. Sometimes shoddy texture work does not detract from the beautiful world Techland has crafted. Performance wise the game runs alright currently. Though pre-patch it ran like complete ♥♥♥ on hardware that should be able to run it perfectly fine. THough even post-patch it still has issues utilising all CPU cores and using SLI properly. There's also the fact that AMD/ATI users are basically ♥♥♥♥ed by Techland's optimisation for their hardware.  WHich is a major issue.The game sadly lacks its own charm and personality. Instead feeling like another new AAA game. There's nothing truly memorable about it. Dead Island had some ridiculous memorable stuff such as Sam B, the wonderous jumping animation and the silly yet unique style. This game has Crane unsure of what to do before proceeding to be silent during actual gameplay. While Dead Island had the characters doing their own ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ yet hilarious one-liners, screams and moans.It just feels oddly generic. Overall it's a game full of ideas, some which it fulfills and some which it stumbles with. It takes a lot of elements from a lot of games, and does some well and some poorly. There's a lot of technical issues and the game can become fairly repetitive. Though ultimately, what is here is a very entertaining and ambitous, though not memorable, game from Techland. I give it a 7.5/10

content:
, 2015
												I got this gift as a gift on May 22. So far, as of typing this out, I have enjoyed myself well beyond what one could. The atmosphere is enjoyable. The game presents a challenge that most games do not provide. The storyline has been nothing short of immersive.The game is essentially if Dead Rising and Borderlands had a child and somehow Mirror's Edge was romantically involved. My ratings so far?Graphics: 8.5/10Reason for rating: There are a few graphical glitches that could be easily remedied with a bit of investigative coding and some of the options are much too overpowering that could be toned down a pinch or be given an option for a lower setting. But for this, the natural bloom and shading makes the game much more menacing when playing, especially during the night in-game, which is -exactly- what I'd expect from something with a dramatic, eerie toned game like this.Storyline: 7/10Reason for rating: To start, the negatives are far outweighed by the positives. The storyline was engaging, however short it was, though my gripes with certain parts could be very notable, further dragging down my potential rating for this section. Subtlety felt lacking in certain parts of the game, especially during the end. Though the aspect was expected, perhaps different approaches could have been made to meet the main points in the story. With that being said, the storyline kept me hooked until one of the end missions.Gameplay: 8.75/10Reason for rating: So far, the enjoyment out of searching for secrets, better gear, and beyond, is what makes the game for me. I absolutely adore open worlds and a good questing system, as it allows for the ability to immerse yourself further by forcing you to explore and see the city of Harran as it is now and get ideas of what it was prior. The crafting system feels familiar yet different in how it's approached. My only bother with crafting like this is that I cannot set macros or access some form of GUI to craft on the fly naturally.My major gripe about this game isn't about the single player aspect, but the multiplayer. When poking and prodding at the "Be The Zombie" game mode, the biggest issue I noticed was the ease of absolutely demolishing the zombie player. While, yes, a good player will not be killed too easily as the Night Hunter, the ability to play "well" is based on what abilities you have at your disposal in comparison to your [up-to-four] human rival[/s]. This makes leveling up extremely hard as the Hunter if you're up against any more than one human player unless the players are foolish enough to split up or you're abusing the system with friends.Balance is a -must- in any game, no matter the mode. Without allowing more health to the Hunter with more players in a server and allowing any level of player into a server, the mode leaves much to be desired and makes it painful to play.Overall, this game, as it stands, despite my biggest spit towards it, is definitely up there in my biggest recommendations.EDIT: Made amendments to my Storyline rating.ADDENDUM: Will add much more when I can buy more DLC to give my view on the game as it stands.

content:
y 30, 2015
												Imagine if a developer took some concepts from Far Cry, Assassin's Creed and Mirror's Edge and kind of threw them on the top of the gameplay from Dead Island. Well, Techland has done just that, it's just that none of the concepts really work that well and all the issues from Dead Island are still prevalent.You kill fast zombies, slow zombies, strong zombies and exploding zombies. You make molotovs, grenades, medkits from items you find in the game world. There's quicktime events and unlockable skills and you've seen them all of this stuff before in some form or another, in any game you've probably played in the last decade.I can't think of a good reason to recommend this game to anyone. At release it is horribly optimized and runs like crap, I've seen all manner of glitches and been victim to countless, cheap deaths. Killing zombies is about as unoriginal as it comes these days and the only time this game is worth picking up is if you see it in a bargain bin and even then, that's a stretch.Full video review:

20, 2016
												Graphics, visual design and possibility of cooperative playthrough make this game AAA coop blockbuster. If you want to play this game alone - it is far from such a perfection so better play with someone.Gameplay, combat and parkour are pretty repetitive. Interesting for first few days but then you will get tired of it. Even after you adapt and learn perks: regular jams in textures, grabs for 'wrong' obstacles, inability to make jumps at certain angles in proximity to objects will occur. I really miss something in every aspect of the game: running is worse than in "Mirror's Edge", combat feedback worse than in "Condemned", script... well... 'obviously simple', tons of similar boring quests and placeholder-music. Call your friends, take a bow or a shotgun and enjoyment will happen. But remember this game is very far from masterpiece, you'll need a lot of patience to make it to the final.

content:
ry 3, 2015
												I love Dead Island. Played it on PS3 and a good 300 hours on Steam.I disliked Dead Island Riptide, 3 playthroughs in 50 hours.This is not a bad game, it's just not a great game. I would consider it good for 20 euro.Aside from graphic problems (wich would be logical with my current rig, but it magicly performs as well as a i7-SLI rig if I compare my monitoring with posts from the forums). Now I did some tweaking but reading high end machines having FPS of 20-40 outside...Chronic Abrretion or how ever you write it. It sucks as much as my spelling. But at least I apoligize for it^^Oke, so the game is running. It's not bad. Parkour does what it needs to do. Remember chasing the thief in AC? sprinting and then your hanging on a plant? this doesn't / hardly happens in Dying Light. BIG PLUS. The zombies. Well, they are good. you got the slow majority, recently turned virals (running) and a few nice specials. At night normal zombies can turn and there is the Violate (Blade III vampire). The pyshics are good, you can really bang those ragdolls up, throw them of roofs / stairs. I was afk-isch and suddely a zombie dropped from a roof, broke it legs and still crouched to try to take a chump out of me. The ragdollphysics are sometimes hillariliously  well done.It goes wrong after level 15. You get better wapons, but the zombies don't get scaled. I have a 2.5K Katana able to 1 kill the biggest badass zombie special. (spoiler alert: he is big and fast and doesn't has a hammer).I'm replaying now, simple because I want 100% completion. Now that's a bad motivation. I doubt if I will replay after this. It's a good game, but it's not worth it's price at 40 euro. It look great, but there is little to no challenge in anything. It's not open worl, it's a lineair storyline on 2 big (great) maps. Exploring isn't really encouraged, you get by most sidequests by following the main story anyway. don't think I'm gonna buy DLC for this either. Unless the scaling gets adressed and the DLC contains a new campaignlike content. So far it seems  wapons (you dont need) and challenges, wich you actually don't want to do.But, buy it for 20, you will have a good game.Returned to this game because a friend bought it during the sale. It's quite good now actually. Runs an awful lot smoother, dipped a bit into the Following, wich looked gorgeous. Went back to Haran because my mate just started a new game.

Looking forward to play the Following with him

I was disgrunted about previous content, but from what I've seen the Following so far, it does justify the cost with it. Hell, im at  130 hours so I consider it all good

content:
y 27, 2015
												Zombie FarCry . . . which is a good thing! 8.5/10, read on for more detail.This game plays in an incredibly similar way to FC3 (and FC4 I'm assuming, although I've yet to play). The graphics are of a similar nature, the handling is similar, the crafting and skills aquisition is similar, the open world environment is similar, the quest system is similar, etc. It really feels familiar if you've played FarCry.That being said, it's obviously got unique elements, such as the parkour movement around the city and the general atmosphere. A+ on graphics (which I run fully maxed out on my i7 4770k, GTX 770 4gb, 16gb rig). Controls are easy enough once you practice. Parkour elements pretty smoothly integrated and intuitive. Combat thus far feels pretty smooth and realistic, although precision hitting with a pipe is proving difficult. Sound is absolutely top notch (hearing things all around me, things sound hellish at night, very immersive).Gameplay is tense and you definitely are presented with a nice balance of feeling like a badass, but also terrified out of your wits at times. Only complaint is sheer amount of cutscenes and times when you sit back and watch, rather than play. I'm OK with these, as I think they add cinematic drama to most games, but it does feel a bit over the top here.No technical issues, install was a breeze, no crashes or bugs yet. So nice to play a AAA title after so many early access games in the last year or two. Overall, great game that I'm looking forward to playing through, then again in co-op.

												This game is not just your casual zombie or surivival game, this is the real stuff. There is no possibility to choose between easy/medium/hard mode. Might wanna get a friend to play with, sometimes its real boring when you are alone. Get a friend and play co-op together. Endless fun.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------PROS+ Astonishing graphics and sun+ AMAZING and unique parkour mechanics+ Crazy and real look alike cinematics+ Beautiful huge urban area to explore+ Able to spend skill points on useful abilities.+ Awesome night time gameplay, real challenging.+ Huge range of weapons+ Crafting system (weapons included)+ Zombies have a different look compared to other Zombie games, makes it original.+ Hundreds of sub-missions+ Active developers team to fix bugs, optimization problems, addition of new graphics, etc.+ Well made story+ Perfect soundtrack that applies to parkour and zombie killing situations.+ Ability to enter almost every house in order to scavenge+ Picklock system+ Co-op with 4 players+ Multiplayer, with the ability to play as the night hunterCONS- Horrible optimization. I couldnt play if it wasnt for that Nvidia driver for Dying Light. But I'm still struggling due to my AMD processor. (Although they are working on fixing it, lets see what they make out of it)- Weapons break faster than they are supposed to. There are even some weapons that can't actually even break in real life.- No suppressors to craft/use on guns.- Stealth is really, but REALLY poor in this game. When you sneak up behind someone you can't snap his neck or even kill him with 1 slash in the head. They are supposed to die right on the impact because they are not aware of it.- Low presence and finding rate of firearms in the game. You simply can't make a zombie game without firearms. Guns are rare in the game and they said that snipers would be available. I couldn't find a single sniper throughout the whole game. Its more a hack and slash game. It gets pretty repetetive slashing zombies all day. I already heard rumors about a DLC weapon pack, if its true I just have one thing to say. Please, no.- Theres no primitive way to survive, like making bows by using a hatch to get wood from trees. Its all about scavenging.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I recommend this game, but it still needs a lot of improvement. This game has a lot to prove due to its active developement team that works on the complaints of players and future additions to the game.

content:
ry 4, 2015
												Definitely a worthy purchase. So far I have barely played into 15% of the story as the sidequests have be going without it feeling like a chore. Day/Night cycle works very subtly and works well. Personally, night does scare me. Even knowing the Volatiles position as they're marked on your minimap you will constantly check your back and when you get chased it becomes very tense. I find the night to be quite balanced, as the volatiles run faster than you but climb slower so you have to take advantage of the mirrors-edge style parkour that the game perfectly placed in, making it a much more interesting version of Dead Island with the free roaming aspect of it - quite unique to input a parkour system into a zombie game, but it was definitely a good mashup. I myself am not even a horror fan and I enjoy this game - it doesn't try to be scary, and usually isn't - fans of Action/RPG games will definitely enjoy this, even if you found Dead Island to be dull.

content:
ry 20, 2015
The parkour movement is fluid but isn't flushed out. The movement feels abit restrictive and in some parts...unrealistic. But you won't notice this unless you are capable of parkouring Offline. The combat feels similar to skyrim, but not entirely the same, you cannot do magic here and you are limited to holding 1 item in our hand at a time. The scare aspect to this...it's just meh. There is weapon detoriation in this game, but unlike most other games..you weapon only has a certain number of repairs it can do until it is worthless. The death mechanic in this game is a joke, you only lose points, which by the way are easily earned back. The story is sum'ed up to "bad-guy vs good-guy" cliche. The online is great for Co-op campaigns but it sucks for zombie invading. Co-op campaigns get a average of 1-3 peps joining you. Trying to invade someone's gets a average of 1-2 games to invade per 10 refreshes. The difficulty is none existant. The maps are clearly designed give you that feeling of "I'm in a city" but I didn't feel that, I just felt like I was running through a maze most of the time. But the rooftops makes travel alot faster, too fast in my book...Oh and the slums map seems like it gotten the most attention, old town and such just seem like they were rushed. the lack of attire and character choices just bothers me. I like being able to play other characters and have many costumes, not be restricted to just 1 character and like only 10 or so costumes to pick from. The crafting is shares similarities to The Last of Us.  The game only autosaves...there is no "save button" here. The game will save whenever you either sleep or get a loading screen or unlock a safe house or when you complete a task. The game also has no fast-travel, so most of your game will consist of running/ jumping. Lastly, the client. The client is stable. During my playtime I never had the game crash once. But, the game does refuse to start in fullscreen mode for me...Oh and the game only works properly for Nvidia Graphics cards, Amd is outta luck here. Tl:drit's a good zombie hunting game with parkour. just not a good story driven game.

content:
y 27, 2015
												Final Review:As I stated in my previous update, this game has some issues with AI and NPC voice acting but these are just little issues in what is an excellent game. Considering this is Techlands first big project, the little issues that do exist are excusable. I'm very much looking forward to their future projects.My overall marks are:Graphics - 9/10Gameplay - 9/10 (would have been 10 if it wasn't for AI issues)Story - 8/10Overall, this is a great game that has enjoable combat mechanics and a decent story. My one other issue is under spoiler alert, which is to do with the end game.****Spoiler Alert****Somewhat disappointed that the final fight amounted to hitting certain buttons when told to in an interactive cut scene. It would not have been hard to design the final fight to be a full on melee battle or gun fight. However, the lead up to that fight was intense and exciting.Update 28/1/15: Still no patch but have managed to get the game to run with an acceptable 30 to 45 fps while out in the open world. Did this by dropping the view distance down to nothing and turning off HBAO. Enjoying the game now, just wish I didn't have to compromise on the graphics.In terms of the game, it is pretty good. I have some gripe with the AI of human NPC's, when going for an air drop I just throw molotovs at them; the NPC's that don't get hit by the molotov just stand there and watch their buddies burn to death. Also, some of the zombie AI is iffy, I have seen human NPCs stand next to zombies, side by side, neither of them attacking the other. The only other negative is that most of the male characters look the same and some of the voices do not fit the faces, so much so that it is comical on occasions.But the game is enjoyable, killing zombies feels good although human AI is predictable. The parkour element is well put together. It may seem that I have more negative to say about the game than I do positive but at the time of writing this I have only played for a few hours. The purpose of this update to my review is to give some feedback on the game itself as my original review was about its poor optimisation. At this stage, even with all its flaws I do recommend this game. I will extend my review at a later date.Beware AMD GPU users, the game may not run very well with your GPU, even if you have a high quality one like I do.Original Review:Right now the game is unplayable as when I am outside my FPS drops below 25. Running with an AMD FX8350 and Radeon R9 270x. Seems to me from looking at the rest of the reviews, this game has been poorly optimized for AMD systems, regardless of what all the Nvidia fanboys are saying.All those having the same issue, go to this link:http://en.support.techland.pl/support/solutions/articles/4000042573-creating-dxdiag-fileSend them a dxdiag file to help them fix these problems more quickly.

content:
ry 10, 2015
												"Why should I bother reading your review?" (Skip this if you want)I've had video gaming as a hobby for 20 years, crossing all genres with a big appetite for survival, horror and RPGs. Hence why I decided to review dying light. I try to stay objective and neutral. Give credit where its due and use the stick where the game deserves to be criticized. Note that I'm a Non-Native English speaker.The GoodThe game has great graphics and the gameplay is fun. Despite the gameplay being repetative, the fun is not severely diminished  - because at its core - it is a very enjoyable "grinder" / sandbox all the way through. The crafting system is very basic, but better to have a basic crafting system than none. The upgrade trees was something I found alarming because though I do love RPG elements, I was afraid the game would become too easy with all these upgrades. However, the game managed to keep the challenge at a rate that always kept me at my toes even with a ton of upgrades. As for sidequests, they are actually kind of interesting in this game. Even a fetch quest can become fun through dialogue or challenge.The Bad (VERY MINOR story spoilers)The variety of opponents in this game is too low imo. But that becomes nitpicking. Because the biggest flaw this game has - is actually the personality of the main character. Though the story isn't that great or imaginative, I would consider it kinda good for what you'd expect from a Zombie game. The main character however, is a nightmare.Your character is a whiny, unprofessional moron who gets emotionally attached to the doomed people of this ruined city. He cries when a story character dies, as if he cares. I had to roleplay that I was faking it. The main character is introduced as an agent whom sole purpose is to retrive a file. Then he starts crying and caring for the people in the city instead of doing his job. The white knight in shining armor of your main character becomes tiresome and obnoxious as he spews out ultra-moralistic crap as if he was the human embodiment of self-rightiousness. The main villain is also uninteresting and cliche and suffers the opposite, by being completely void of humanity and just "evil for the sake of evil". TO SUM UP:Though I personally never cared about graphics (i still consider Fallout 2, Morrowind and ff7 the best games out there) the graphics in this game is really good. But you need a decent rig.The gameplay itself is great. It is fun despite being repetative.Crafting system and upgrade system is good.The challenge is not so hard that it becomes overly frustrating, but neither as easy that you risk to become bored.Enemies are varied enough, but just barely, there should have been 1-3 more types of enemies.The story itself is average, but better than I expected for a zombie survival. Side quests are surprisingly satisfying!What really pulls the score down imo is the lack of some things in the story, like joining factions or faction vs faction assault/defense in the storyline, NPCs you genuinely care about etc. BIGGEST OFFENDER is the main character and the main villain, they are both horribly written and it is impossible to symphatize with either. Your character is too "good" on the morality scale, at the point of it almost becoming repulsive. The main villain is unimaginatively written and is the standard one dimensional "evil for the sake of evil" boring archetype. Near the end of the game I hated the main character more than the villain. All in all, 7.8/10 - I recommend this game.If you like sandbox games, zombie apocalypse scenarios, survival games, horror and RPG elements and have a good PC, you will probably find this game worth the money. Do not however - expect the story, the main character or the main villain to provide any intellectual or emotional satisfaction on any level unless you are younger than 16 years old.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 9, 2015
													Dying Light is a mostly fun zombie-slaying game that utilizes parkour. It's brought to you by the creators of the first Dead Island and Dead Island: Riptide, Techland. Dying Light outshines Dead Island greatly, even with its launch issues. It features better writing, a greater sense of verticality that works well with the parkour and grappling hook, skill trees that make progression feel more significant, graphic and enjoyable combat, a fearsome night, some bugs, and questionable design decisions that did not sit well with me.	The story has one main protagonist instead of a cast of four a la Dead Island. You play as Kyle Crane, an undercover GRE (Global Relief Effort) agent sent to recover a file lost within the city of Harran. As Crane, you bear witness to the insane brutality and sadness that affect the survivors of the devastated city. Dying Light managed to present an okay, passable story that did not make my eyes glaze over as if I were one of the undead. The main antagonist was crafted to be obviously evil and fond of diabolical plans which came off as cheesy or cliché at times. The writing lacked the finesse to not be predictable. However, some of the side-quests were very well done with how they portrayed loss and grief. On the other hand, the game definitely could have done without the useless find x number of item side quests that served no purpose or told any stories.	Dying Light's world is generally fun to navigate due to the winning mixture of parkour and well used vertical space. Although, sometimes you will find yourself falling down and taking damage due to learning what can and cannot be grabbed, a feeling that's amplified with the use of the grappling hook. You will need to learn how to use its lock-on on ledges before channeling Just Cause's Rico Rodriguez since you can grapple onto most surfaces, including the ground. Unfortunately, Kyle Crane cannot use the grappling hook on zombies. The parkour keeps on improving as you level up the Agility tree and chain maneuvers. Do you want to vault off a zombie and dropkick another zombie into spikes or vault off a railing to drop two stories below, avoid damage by rolling, and then continue to run about? It feels like Mirror's Edge's lite with its own style, but no wall running.	The world of Dying Light uses height well. The first major area in the game is in a poorer part of Harran filled with shops, abandoned vehicles, cheap housing, incomplete skyscrapers, a large highway, a sweet bridge, radio towers, a coast, and open areas to run across. The second major area is dense with buildings which plays very well with the grappling hook and jumping around in general. I greatly enjoyed hopping between two story lampposts to cross a plaza or scrambling up buildings to avoid Volatiles during night. Yes, there are radio towers, but during those sequences I thought the game produced a nice sense of height as wind sounds and camera tilting worked to make me nervous. I think only three of them are part of the critical path for the story, so do not worry.	They did a good job with making the points in the skill trees feel significant. There are very few skills that have mundane percentage increases and focus more on adding more to the gameplay via new techniques or recipes. You can end up with throwing stars that can freeze zombies, a spinning attack, an upgraded slide to break knees, or the ability to squash the heads of enemies frolicking on the ground. Skill points greatly affect the way you move, fight, and items you can craft.	The combat has a slow start, but turns into a slaughterfest as strikes start cleaving enemies into two, horizontally and vertically. They could have balanced it better to make the beginning more impactful and prevent the p. I found a great amount of joy in using advanced abilities to destroy hordes of zombies and pesky humans. The humans tend to be much more dangerous when engaging them in melee, especially early in the game. However, you can easily dispatch them with molotovs or grenades if you do not have a firearm handy. I popped heads like watermelons, drop kicked zombies into various environmental hazards, lured enemies into traps, and much more. There should be enough gore in Dying Light for the zombie enthusiast. The zombies come with a bit of variety too. You have normal zombies (Biters), Virals (the runners), Goons, Volatiles (the scary ones), Toads, Bombers, Demolishers, Screamers, hazmat Biters with explosive gas tanks on their back, and Night Hunters if you allow pvp. You will not be killing Volatiles in the beginning. They have multiple attacks and need to be weakened before attacking them. Co-op makes them less scary once your group has decent weapons and support items available, but carelessness will still result death. Co-op is a fun and silly experience with occasional desync hiccups that result in weird physics on bodies.	The night in Dying Light creates an unfriendly environment filled with tension. The night makes zombies more aggressive, allows Volatiles to come out of their nests, and introduces a four level alert system. The more trouble you cause, the higher the alert level becomes causing many angry zombies to converge on your position. I would recommend carefully killing some regular zombies during the night because experience for both Agility and Power are doubled with a bonus to Survivor level as night ends. Co-op tends to trivialize the night experience if everyone is packing flares unless it is a level four alert. The grappling hook also makes night easier until you miss the ledge of a three story building during a chase. God help you if that happens.	This game had some issues upon release with many of them resolved. They are still working on additional issues. You can read through this thread to see a comprehensive list of different bugs: http://steamcommunity.com/app/239140/discussions/0/604941528488544773/ I personally experienced four bugs: a waypoint that wouldn't disappear from the map, a ledge on an optional radio tower that sent me out of bounds (I could swim back in), being unable to interact after killing enemies with a gun and then switching weapons (patched), and the inability to reach max Survivor level. Not bad with a system that did not meet minimum specs except for RAM.	There were some design choices that did not do the game justice here. The sound design for the guns felt flaccid because they fired as if they all had suppressors. Then the game had a few, annoying deaths that made me bitter. They tend to happen in this manner: you go into a room and a Bomber bursts through a door and kills you instantly or you open a door and are greeted by a Bomber or two. At one point in the game, they change the behavior of a hazmat zombie so that it runs toward you and detonates. That kind of design adds nothing to the gameplay or enjoyment of the game. Co-op can help mitigate those situations, but not always. Thankfully, the number of those incidents remains below ten. The game make use of too many camera effects with the long lasting water effect that blurs your screen for far too long irking me the most. There are no options available to turn those effects off. At this time, you will need to mod them out and a good place to start is http://www.nexusmods.com/dyinglight/ I know some people do not like those obnoxious effects or film grain. Weapon variety suffers from blunt weapons leaving the weapon pool at higher Survivor levels. Finally, the ending was mechanically disappointing and completely out of place.	Dying Light is not a perfect game. It has its flaws, but it is much, much better than Dead Island and is much closer to achieving that wonderful zombie slaying game I have always wanted. The improved movement adds so much to the game when it comes to combat and navigation. The drop kicks are fantastic.

content:
y 28, 2015
												Man, I really can't formulate my thoughts right now -- this was *exactly* the game I was waiting for a really, really long time.Okay, first of all -- so much props to Techland for stepping up and making everything they have planned, and so much more.Dying Light is easily the best sandbox zombie FPS out there, and the best AAA game of 2015 (already, yeah). Techland outdid themselves with this one -- you can consider Dying Light a perfected version of Dead Island (the first sandbox zombie FPS, I think). Graphics, sounds, music, atmosphere, script -- everything was perfected, and released with practically no delays (something for Ubisoft to learn here).If you don't know what to expect from the game, watch the E3 trailer -- the game is *exactly* like the trailer. Which is so hard to believe, actually, isn't it? Well, trust me: I've tried everything they were doing in the trailer -- and it works perfectly: throwing zombies, setting traps, jump-kicking, throwing weapons, running through your course of traps from infected, looking back at them, setting off your traps...And by all means, try the co-op mode, AND the "Be The Zombie" mode -- both are absolutely amazing. Co-op in this game is a lot better than in Dead Island (it was meaningless there) -- I can tell you this much.This game deserves the highest rating, this easily can be the game of the year, I honestly mean that. I'd rate it 10.0 out of 10.0, a most certain "must buy".

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
												I'd appreciate it if you checked out my blog, where I do reviews, giveaways, and more: https://gandhigaming.wordpress.com/I think we can all agree, 2014 was definitely not the best year for gaming by a long shot. And even though it gave us gems like Alien: Isolation or Shadow of Mordor, it was arguably one of the worst years of gaming ever. Dying Light is the first "major" release of 2015, and I was worried for this game because I thought the 2014 curse would still linger on and affect this game. Luckily, I was wrong. Very, very wrong.Now, although I enjoy Dying Light, it has various flaws to the game that doesn't make it the ultimate zombie experience we were all looking for. But that being said, Dying Light is a great game and an awesome way to start 2015, and it makes me think that this year will be much better than 2014.GraphicsProbably one of the best things to Dying Light, the graphics look absolutely stunning on PC. Every little bit to the game is detailed. Don't believe me? Check out some of these screenshots I took:http://cloud-4.steamusercontent.com/ugc/541896836997986793/D10F15E8921F2BD6BFF6FB7E2191E84224205244/http://cloud-4.steamusercontent.com/ugc/541895566612870024/11FFA702F3E89B9735B1A77FC8647D96F91D5BD2/This game continues to wow me with how beautiful the game is and even rivals modded Skyrim. The atmosphere, which may seem to make the game look like a generic 90000000 zombies vs. 1 man is actually a bit dark and depressing. No, it's not anywhere near as bad as say The Last of Us, but it isn't cheery. And when night comes, things get intense quick. You can barely see, which means you'll have to use your flashlight, but then in the shadows a Volatile (a superzombie of sorts) will be watching you and trying to strike you. On my very first night, I was running back to my home base, which was somewhat far away, and my heart was racing when I heard one of those things scream. I didn't bother looking back and I had an adrenaline rush. Luckily, I made it back. But this proves that the nights are hectic, intense, and heart-racing. The graphics and atmosphere to Dying Light are some of the best I've seen in a while, and it was done right.GameplayDying Light is a bit different from zombie games in the fact that it uses parkour to get around. And this part I was very worried about, because all the parkour games I've played had god awful parkour, not to name any names. And for the first 5-6 hours or so, I thought my fears came true. However, I got adjusted to the controls and it turns out that all of it is silky smooth. The parkour is great, and jumping from one building to another never felt so nerve-racking and exhilarating. The combat is also good in this game. Instead of going in guns blazing, you have to plan your way to get through a horde of zombies. You can sneak past them with firecrackers or some other distraction, take them out from a distance and use molotovs, or maybe you are just that crazy and you want to go in and kill them all (although you probably won't survive to kill three). The game is over the top in some ways, but it still keeps a sense of realism and doesn't ruin the fun. For example, you have combat stamina and your character can get worn out, giving the zombies an edge. Also, guns are extremely rare to find, and I didn't get one until at least 9hrs into the game, and bullets are even rarer. Weapons can break, you can upgrade them, etc. As for the night mode, it is only scripted to change in the earlier missions, but then the time is free and night can come at any moment. The game is difficult to an extent, the other zombie types make the game much more interesting at night, and the list could go on and on and on. My one issue, however, is that once you get your hands on more powerful items, the late game becomes very easy and the experience can be ruined, killing the atmosphere and immersion. But besides that, overall, the gameplay is smooth and it was executed well.StoryIt's pretty obvious that this would be the game's low point. I figured this would have a cheap story, and I was right. A one-dimensional protagonist I can't seem to become interested in, and one-dimensional characters everywhere actually. Jade is the stereotypical heroine, with her "I'm 1000% more badass than you" style, Dr. Zere is all about "saving the world" and doesn't get any further than that, Rais is a brutal leader (you don't say?), must I continue? It's a generic save-the-world plot that I can't get into. However, I will give credit to the story for being depressing, because many people (won't name anyone specific) die left and right. Few zombie games seem to understand that it's no easy feat, and so kudos to the writers for keeping that in mind. I don't want to elaborate any further because I'm sure you know where I'm going with this. Generic story, one dimensional characters, boring protagonist...AudioThe audio is good but nothing to write home about. The zombies actually sound somewhat scary and not silly, so that's something worth noting. The voice actors aren't bad either, but the characters are still one dimensional. I also like the fact that the soundtrack doesn't use guitars to make it seem depressing or heavy metal/electronic mix to make me mistaken this game for Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance. Yes, it has a mostly electronic soundtrack, but it isn't upbeat. It's slow, somewhat soothing, and fits the mood. Not only that, but because the game takes place in Turkey, it adds a few personal touches to make the soundtrack even better. ReplayabilityThe replayability seems somewhat good. Co-Op is a blast to play and can bring hours and hours of fun, plus finding all the clever easter eggs can be quite enjoyable. You can also try and get all the god-tier weapons and then kill the most deadly zombies in 1-2 hits with no problem. At this point, this is where the replayability begins to fade. As I stated earlier, once you get all the good stuff, the game becomes too easy and kills any atmosphere or suspense. Not only that, but Be the Zombie mode was one of the key reasons I bought this game and it turned out to be very boring and unbalanced. Playing as the zombie is fun, but the survivors with Survivor Sense already won pretty much and it ruins the stealth and suspense buildup the game mode attempts to offer. The replayability though isn't that bad and I may play a few hours postgame to do a few things.VerdictDying Light is not the best game I've played in 2015 so far. However, it's still a blast to play and worth the money if you're fine with a few flaws with the game. In the end, I recommend Dying Light to any big zombie gamers out there, and I'd be more than happy to buy this game again and replay it through.Graphics- 10/10Gameplay- 8.5/10Story- 4.0/10Audio- 7.0/10Replayability- 6.0/10.:7.9/10:.+Smooth parkour+Stunning graphics+Fun co-op+Intense night mode+Keeps a sense of realism-Be the Zombie mode is boring and unbalanced-Generic story with one-dimensional characters and boring protagonist-Late game becomes very easy and ruins all suspense

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2015
												I'm sorry if this review is not that great, I just want to jump right back in and play more.I've finished the game and I'm now playing the Newgame+. There are more DLC planned including a new huge area bigger than all of harran, and dune buggies and a whole crapload of other awesome stuff, but until then, here's my review of the vanilla game. Graphics: 7/10	The game looks very good, but for many of us PC gamers, the texture pop-ins and the medium res textures can be of annoyance. However, this is one of those games where graphics are secondary to the gameplay. Not to say the graphics are bad at all, they aren't, but it leaves allot of Titan cards bored. The graphics and overall aesthetic of the game is atmospheric and does work, but leaves me wanting higher resolution textures and a MUCH better option menu. Sound: 10/10	I am a huge audiophile, I only accept the very best sound, no distortion, no jaggy treble, and this game is definitely to my satisfaction. The sound is all there, the footsteps, the grass, the sound of your weapon swinging and the soft sound of the rain is all jaw dropping in how well recorded/generated it is. Sound is not too important for allot of gamers, but if you're like me and you want the best of the best in your ears, pick this game up. Sounds great on my Sennheiser HD518's. Gameplay: 9/10	The gameplay is a huge strong point of the game. The combat flows extremely well, the parkour flows even better, and chaining them both together will give you a bloody amazing gameplay experience. The gameplay takes the very best parts from Dead Island, and Assassins Creed/Mirrors Edge and slams those games and shows them how it's done. This game does the tower climbing better than Far Cry 3, Combat better than Dead Island, and Parkour better than Assassins Creed. I can't even begin to explain how satisfying the combat is, but just imagine running up a wall, jumping off, and in mid-air, dropkicking a zombie into a pit of spikes, or throwing a gas tank next to a big zombie and watch it smash the tank and explode. Completed this game, and I am not done at all. Story: 5/10	Meh. Nothing new here. The story was alright in the first half of the game, but the drug sequence, and the "CRAAAAAAAANE" literally made me cringe. They also gave us very few oppurtunities to connect with the characters that died, and the emotional way Crane bursts out just seems ridiculous given how he barely knew the people who just died, whilst he shoots looters in the face.Little things:Replayable? YesIs it scary at night? Yes, when you start off.Does it run well? Not even on my GTX 970, but that doesnt make the game less enjoyable.Are the devs still active? Yes, they seem to be very active and they engage with their fans very frequently.Eh. There's your review. I'm just gonna submit this and play more. More stuff is coming, the game is fun, it's on sale at the time of writing this review, and it's probably my GOTY.

content:
y 28, 2015
												Imagine Dead Island that's actually a well-made video game without most of the annoying/stupid stuff. Featuring a great parkour system and a meaningful day/night cycle. And Arabs (or whatever imaginary people they are)... for some reason.Looks very polished and is a technically impressive good looker overall with the aesthetic that sets just the right mood (acceptable texture artworks; great lightning effects and shadows: the nights are dark and full of terrors; one of the best drawing distances ever coupled with the possibility of cranking level of detail to insane levels even on the furthest objects, which require very powerful machine). The game feels well-paced in terms of story and activities and balanced in every gameplay aspect. Skill progression is mostly enjoyable and worthwhile along with the functional crafting system.It is true, however, that the game is an ultimate hodgepodge of gameplay mechanics burrowed from dozens of predecessors with not that many new ideas, but the end result is worth it.Also the game fully supports Dualshock 4 (Playstation 4 controller) with the correct button prompts without any additional software requirements (no need to emulate Xbox controller, for instance).

content:
ry 1, 2015
												Dying Light. + Graphics look nice. + Fun combat. + Solid freerunning. + Diverse tactics. + Good day/night cycle. + Fun pvp mode. + Fun coop mode + challenges. + Challenging early on. + Decent upgrade system. + Interesting sidequests, some even tearjerking. + Nice backstory/lore. // Average story - Quite typicall, predictable. // Halfbad lipsync. // Abit buggy here and there. (No AC-Unity don't worry).// Lack of player choice. - Male characters look the same, this is a bigg issue. 50%-70% of the male characters look like the NPC Gazi with different facial hair, even important quest npcs etc.   - Nothing to really do after maxlevel. After maxing all skills, you feel like nothing is worth doing since you only get minimal to no reward for doing things (sideobjectives, airdrops, save survivor etc.), would have been nice to see some kind of system in place to counter this. - All  your friends look the same in Co-op except if you have unlocked different costumes, feels quite silly. - Lack of player customization (bad design), they decided to use clothing for different slots (example: Hats gloves, shooes etc.) but you can only equip them as a full coustume instead of combining it for your self.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
ry 2, 2015
												Dying Light is basically what Dead Island games should've been: fast, fun and solid zombie survival game with pretty large open world.Most of the time you are going to be doing parkour. And it's pretty well made - closest implementation to the fantastic movement system of Mirror's Edge I'd seen by the date.Fighting zombies is, of course, also an option - if not for loot, then for survival. And the combat system although somewhat similar to Dead Island is quite much more fast paced and visceral. Oh, and throwable weapons actually are useful here.All of that is wrapped up into nice leveling system with three talent trees - survival (general skills), agility (moving skills) and power (fighting skills). Some of the skills are unique and pretty interesting (e.g. grappling hook), while most of them are disappointingly plain upgrades (e.g. weapons durability degrades slower).And then you have to balance between day and night, because those times feel like two completely different games. At day most of zombies are dumb, slow and, well, boring. At night unless you act carefully (or sleep in a safehouse), you'll get you ♥♥♥ bitten off pretty quickly.Throw in couple of competing factions, very good voice acting, pretty large world, random events, challenges and all those other open world things - and you'll get a pretty solid game. There's nothing new in it, really. But it's so well made that it's a joy to roam around.On the downsides:- Engine is still not very well optimized, FPS tends to randomly sink for no apparent reason- Some NPCs faces are reused a bit too much (although the voice acting is unique, which feels even stranger)- Night zombies are not too much of a threat once you'd figured out how they think and moveBut if you do enjoy some first-person zombie survival - then this game is definitely one to take a look at.A bit more in-depth look in the video:


YouTube™ Video: DevLook at.. Dying Light 

			Views: 137		

			First impressions of the zombie survival game Dying Light. Dying Light is an action survival game presented in first-person perspective. The game is set in a vast and dangerous open world.
