content:
ry 6, 2015
												At the end of the day, as much as one is inclined to, it is difficult to find fault with a game like Dying Light. Aesthetically, the game is a pleaser. In terms of performance on the PC platform, save for the fps related issues on release week, Dying Light performs respectably even on a mediocre rig. On a high-end rig, Dying Light chugs along at the highest settings with nary a hiccup. As for its gameplay, the action in Dying Light is fast and fluid. Combat is flashy as well as impactful, and killing zombies has never felt more brutally satisfying. The parkour mechanic, which is your character’s main form of locomotion in Dying Light, is also somewhat intuitive, save for a few logical inconsistencies. If your gut tells you that a bridge’s truss is traversable to reach its top, you are unlikely to be wrong. Scaleable aspects of a building are very well-differentiated from those that you can’t interact with. Thus whether it is crisscrossing Harran’s rooftops, or climbing to the top of a clock tower to catch the setting sun, Dying Light’s parkour mechanic makes it both hassle-free and a pleasure to explore its vast and interesting setting. There is no mistake about it, Techland has done an admirable job here: Dying Light is one hell of a game to play, whether alone or in a group. Unfortunately, Dying Light has about as much of a heart or soul as the cold and ruthless GRE boss that your character works for.  I could blame the game’s lack of spirit on its poor storyline, as many other critics have done. I could also blame it on the half-arsed supporting characters that the game seemingly throws at you by the dozen, only to then either arbitrarily kill them off or to leave their relationship with your character hanging by a thread and incomplete. Rather I am going to attribute it to Techland’s failure to make any of the interesting features, that it implements in a seemingly laundry-list like manner, into a mainstream component that properly defines Dying Light and what it stands for. Take the game’s setting in Harran for example. Yes, Harran is a vast and spacious open-world in which players can explore to their hearts’ content. Yes Harran is both beautiful, in a morbid kind of way, and immersive. Yet Techland barely utilizes it to further engage and immerse Dying Light’s players. There is a wafer-thin amount of dynamic events in Harran, which usually exists in the form of survivors fending off zombies, or Rais’ goons sitting idly on top of one of the air-supply crates which the game sporadically generates. Harran also remains the same dreary and worn out place that it was when your character first stumbled into it like the ‘experienced’ secret operative that he is, until the moment you dispose of your main nemesis and complete the game’s main storyline. Converting one of its zone into a safehouse may result in you visually pushing or toppling a couple of shelves or cupboards over, as a form of barricading, but there is otherwise no obvious visual cues that suggest Harran is changing or evolving as a result of your character’s actions. Neither does its inhabitants become better off as you fulfil the usually tedious tasks that they set you out to do. An extreme example is the game’s escort missions, where completing one of them merely returns the relevant NPC that you successfully protected back to his or her starting spot, ready to offer you the same mission again. As a result, playing in Harran can occasionally provide a disconnected experience, one where you realize that nothing your character does ever truly matters. On the other hand, do I think that Dying Light is a game worthy of your money, even at full-price? Yes it is. The game is extremely well-polished and has a good amount of content for you to sink your teeth into. Parkouring your way through the game’s numerous side missions is also an addictive experience. I can’t count the number of occasions where I had originally set out to spend 15 minutes on one of the game’s side mission, only to have those minutes turn into hours as I explore, craft, and decapitate or bash zombie heads in. It’s most unfortunate that Dying Light’s absence of a heart and soul, as a result of Techland’s relative lack of ambition, means that it will remain a game that is a distance aways from being a truly great one. This in itself does not detract from the fact that Dying Light is through and through an entertaining game to play. And entertain you it most certainly will.

content:
ry 8, 2015
												A very good game from Techland. Although there are some strong elements taken straight from the Dead Island franchise (played both of those, not completed), the parkour element really adds something fresh to the zombie-survival genre, not to mention the day-night cycle that changes how you interact with the zombies. I also like the difficulty curve, which makes you a dumb survivor with barebone weapons and pathetic stamina at the start of the game. It may be weird to some people, but I feel this makes you really feel like a newbie survivor trying to learn how to survive. It will only take you a few hours to get useful skills and strong weapons, but it has enough things to do to make the game still interesting for a long while. Weirdly, for me some of the side missions' story are better than the main storyline. Another thing for me to praise is the atmosphere and the environment of the game. Compared to Dead Island, this game have some areas that really gave me chills (a personal issue, definitely). Even when you have a ton of powerful weapons and skills, you are never 100% invulnerable to the zombies. Overall, I love this game, a lot. It will be very interesting to see what Techland have in mind for the future of the franchise. I definitely hope they won't do another "riptide".

y 27, 2015
												If you liked the game play of Dead Island (questing, crafting, and zombie killing) and were OK with the movement in Mirror's Edge (jumping here to there), then you will like this game.(See my "UPDATE" below.)I will note that the jumping mechanic can be frustrating at times and has some issues that you have to learn, but it's pretty solid. I also tried out the "Be The Zombie" mode, and found it to be interesting but not very impressive. It felt very much like playing the alien in Aliens VS Predator (minus the wall crawling mechanics of course).Overall, I'm sure I'll sink a few dozen hours into the game as I did with the Dead Island series.UPDATE:I have been enjoying this game, but have two painful issues to report...1.) When you play "Be The Zombie" you can not invade a friend's game the same way you can co-op. They did not use the same friends awareness menu. That REALLY Kills the feature. Now, you can see games near you (low ping) that you can jump into, but not being able to play with friends easily really, really sucks.2.) During cut scenes, I very often hear the speech, but the animation time slows down or continues for a few seconds after the audio is done. So it really saps the immersion when this occurs....still, I am enjoying the core game. But am VERY disappointed about the Be The Zombie mode not being readily available through the same CO-OP menu.

ry 8, 2015
												This game is fun pretty much identicle to Dead island but better. Its very laggy for anyone without a good computer so I recoomend you get this to expand your options and get the most FPS: ( http://www.nexusmods.com/dyinglight/mods/18/? ) Its anoying how broken and glitchy some parts are though. For example, if you have low FPS then its impossible for you to 100% the game because of how broken challanges are (Not like they are any fun or lead up to anything special, just a time waster) Anyway, if you have low FPS then your game will run slower, however all challanges have a timer and my god is this stupid but the timer counts down faster then it would if you had 30+ FPS. If you dont belive me try an agility challange ranked "medium" with less then 10 FPS and see if its even possible to reach the second to last checkpoints of ANY challange. I kid you not there is only 2 ways of fixing problems like these: Get that graphical mod in the link above and set everything to TF2 graphics just to do the challanges or use Cheat Engin. Last bit of rant is that I sometimes (often) start up the game hearing distorted sound and audio with clicking in the background. I cant find any fix or update for any hardware/software for this and its only random it appears in the game but not many people have this. The grappler is also buggy, sometimes it doesnt want to work and sometimes it wont let you grab onto anything after it pulls you in (Which is suicide). Finally, this isnt really much of a survival game because med kits are so easy to make that you wont ever run out of them later on, same for orange/legendary/unique weapons, you can just buy one and keep using it until you need an upgrade.Sooo, if you have a crappy computer then maybe consider passing on it unless you dont mind TF2 graphics, if you have a great computer then I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
ry 1, 2015
												Heads up, game fans! It's time to review the new zombie apocalypse game that so many people are playing and talking about: Dying Light. I've had a taste, and I want more, but will you? Read along and hopefully find out. I'm not going to tell you everything, and I'm trying to avoid any serious spoilers, but I will give you just a taste so that you can judge for yourself. Please keep in mind that this review is current as of the date of publication, but I have no idea what features may change, improve or get nerfed after this point. I am not including in this review aspects of the DLC, but I may review that later. Or not.If I had to give just a brief idea of what this game is like, take a little bit of Fallout 3, just the tiniest taste of Crysis, a dash of Skyrim, a sprinkling of Far Cry 2, a little more FC2, toss in some inspiration from L4D2, and then top it all off with some Mirror's Edge, and you might get an idea of what this game is like. Maybe. Also throw in some optional asymmetrical fps with some rather unfortunate choices on the part of the developer to get even closer to the full experience. You start off parachuting into a situation in a quarantined city somewhere seemingly in the Middle East. You have to find that one guy that your organization needs you to find; you know the one. You get infected, and you need medicine. That's how you're compromised, and that's how you begin working your way into the local sitch. You make yourself at home and begin doing odd jobs to improve your standing, gather intel, and make reports back to the peeps in charge in the rear. You can probably guess where this is going, so that's all I'm going to say about the back story. If you don't get medicine regularly, you get sicker and could possibly turn. So far it hasn't affected my gameplay as much as the same mechanic that was used in Far Cry 2, but I haven't gone very far in the main story line either. In the relatively brief time I've played this game, I've only had convulsions the one time. You spend all your time climbing, running, jumping, ducking, dodging, and generally trying to outmaneuver, overpower, or out-think your opponents. You constantly have to think about where you're going next and how. The game has freedom, but with it also comes a terrible price. Sometimes you choose wrong, and it hurts so bad when you do. Conversely, when you choose well, and it works, it feels really good, too.You get three skill trees, each with a different focus--one for gear, one for agility, and one for power. The things you do build your skills in the respective area, and if you want to get better at something, try doing it repeatedly or things closely related to it. Craft items and you'll be able to craft more items. Take on zombies one on one in melee, and you'll get better at it. Try extreme stunts, and you'll become a world-class parkour... -er (actually, the proper term is "traceur" if you didn't know... I didn't). Your opponents are a blend of frightening zeds with some specials mixed in who will not always stand out at a distance the way they will in L4D2. Once you know what you're looking for they will be all too apparent in most cases, but there is a slight learning curve involved. Yes, the big guy with the insane hammer is easily spotted in any crowd, but the little screechy ones not so much. There is a level of unpredictability to every encounter. One guy goes down with a single blow, another saps your weapon of its remaining strength. Be wary of that. Weapons can only be repaired a few times. Also, if you upgrade a basic weapon, apparently you cannot then use it as part of crafting an advanced weapon. And when you can no longer repair a weapon, don't forget to dismantle it for the spare bits.You can find a lot of loot everywhere you turn, but most of it (especially the better stuff) is behind locks that you can pick. If you've played Skyrim, you shouldn't have any issues doing this. I've heard Thief players should also know what's what. If you've played neither of those, watch a video before playing your first time to get a sense of how it's done. If somebody says you need tons of picks everytime you go looting, don't listen to them. You only need tons of picks to practice with until you're good. Skyrim players who've already cut their teeth on these locks should have no issue even with the toughest locks in this game.During the day it's a parkour rpg with FPS elements, but at night, if you're out, it's totally stealth. At least until you know what you're doing. Bold precision pays off in this game. The developers have relied on player fear to a good extent, but how can you know the limits until you have tested them. Climb to the top of that communications tower. You never know what you might find. Plan your exit strategy and then hit that guy with the tank on his back. After he explodes, if you survive the swarm that will descend upon you, you will come out the other side stronger for it. Stronger or more agile, or both. Make your painful mistakes early on, because if you wait until later, you will feel the pain as you lose tons more points as a higher level character dies for the mistake of not being bold early on. Clear all your safe zones straight out from the prologue before you complete any quests. I did it my first day after the prologue, with the exception of the last one which was too well defended.  I think the daylight cycle might be tied to story progression and perhaps even side quests. Also, another pro-tip, if you're stuck, consider leaving the game and coming back because there are still glitches and bugs to be worked out. Can't reach a certain post from the roof of that one building? Maybe you're not supposed to. Trust me and see.If you want to know what awaits you in the dark, play the Be a Zombie mode. You get to play as the Hunter, which feels like a cross between a vampire or werewolf and Venom. You get to play as one, that is, if you can find a match where people don't automatically leave as soon as you join. In my experience almost every one of the matches where I was actually able to stay and play, the human players knew what to do. If you decide to play this mode, expect some frustrations as a result, from the learning curve or from the game mechanics or from the matchmaking system. Being the Hunter is fun, but frustrating--until you get better at it. And you will get better if you stick with it. I feel the system is kind of limiting and almost misleading, because you aren't playing as any of the other zombies, only the Hunter.One of the poor choices I feel the developer has made is seen in the multiplayer part of the game. You have extremely limited options in controlling online game play, and the game doesn't distinguish between sides. Say you go into Be a Zombie mode and open your game to public games online, when you go back into your solo campaign, it's not solo anymore. You have to go back into online settings and set it to solo once more. I wonder if this isn't part of the reason behind the large number of players who quit when a Hunter joins their game. Also, apparently, though I have yet to play with friends on co-op, I can tell you the voice communications in multiplayer are set to be strictly always on or always off. No push-to-talk. Perhaps they will fix this in the next patch. We can hope. Until then, better consider your third party options for game chat. Headphones, people. Wear. Your. Headphones. And play in a quiet area or turn off your mic please, for the love of all that is good and true.There are ugly sores on the backside of this game. The repetition of certain dialogue branches when you walk past certain NPC's is irritating. The feeling that I've played this game before, especially when it feels a lot like those other games I listed at the beginning of this review, is a little disappointing. But where the game shines, it shines. I'm out of characters... See ya next t

content:
ber 27, 2015
												TL;DR - This game in my opinion is easily the #1 in its genre and there is very little reason to skip it. Offers fun gameplay and combat with good variety.If you want an open-world zombie ''survival'' game, this one is the best in the market. Hell, even if you just want a game that contains zombies, this is the best one you'll find.Now, i put ''survival'' in quotations (or whatever its called) because you collect things around the world to craft bombs, weapons, med kits and all that. It's not entirely survival and if anyone claims so, i would disagree. It is sort of post-apocalyptic which makes it look survival, but there is no nutritional crisis, where you'd have to go look for food before you starve, so in my opinion its not a survival game.The game is well-ported in my opinion, i have a pretty bad PC and can run it quite fine, and the graphics are quite pleasant too (you need to know what settings to tune down though).What can be annoying for some here is that all weapons are degradable and will be destroyed to uselessness as you use them. You can repair them, but only for a fixed amount of times. What's good with this system however, is that it keeps your weapon variety going and keeps the game interesting in combat to a slight degree (This becomes less of a struggle as the game goes when you can obtain really good stuff too easily).The zombies are really braindead, but you have some empowered ones that can be pretty tough at times. At night time, you'll have some extremely hard monsters to deal with and its almost never recommended to be out at night unless you want a huge adrenaline rush because it can be insanely hard, sometimes scary. In a nutshell they're really fun to fight.Story has some plot to it but i assume its nothing special, since people never take stories in open world games seriously as far as i know, but i enjoyed the story. It was nice to follow it along, and it made you feel pretty important, though you're more like just a running slave.The side-activities arent as interesting but if you want to punch more zombies, they're quite nice. Some involve parkour and gathering aswell. This game supports lots of mods, and there is even custom games where people create their own maps. As soon as we get more content in on this, this could be tons of fun with others or just alone. I'd say this the core ''end'' game you'll be spending your time with after you complete the story, unless you wanna mess around some more over there.

content:
er 28, 2016
												     What's interesting about this game is the story and how it evolves throughout the game. It takes place in a fictional city called Harran. Landmarks and people of the city are simply astonishing. Considering the place, it is away from zombie stereotypes, a zombie apocalypse in middle east is a clever and unique idea in my opinion. I was gonna say they could've done the story better but after the Following dlc there was nothing to say. Beautifully connected and the next story was much more interesting and mysterious. I loved how religion placed into the story. I played for the story and probably stayed for the music, it put me into the game and left me suffer. I also loved how the music reflects their environment it was so correct and well done.     Game functions are easy to understand and skill trees are simple and well organized. Weapon crafting is quite fun and creative since using a gun is not a good idea in an environment like this. Co-op is really nice and fun when you have no balls to go out during night. You can continue from your story or your friend's story without any confusion.

er 5, 2016
												AMAZING combat, AMAZING movement and AMAZING everything. I have racked up a good 30+ hours all alone and there are still things to do. It's a mix between Farcry 3/4 and Dead Island as you can explore the map and clear out "safe zones" and the combat feels just like Dead Island's with the satisfying crunches as you hit the Zombies.The DLC "The Following" is basically an extended campaign but adds in many awesome things such as the Buggy, weapons and more quests. The map for the DLC is also amazing as it takes place in a much different area than the base game, it has mountains, waterfalls and even a racetrack for the Buggy.One of the first games that I could play by my self without getting bored, definetely worth the money.

content:
0, 2015
												Dying Light is more than just your average zombie apocalypse game.Dying Light allows you traverse an open world mired into chaos and destruction. In this environment, you scrap for survival against an array of enemies as the infected are not the only threat: accosting other desperate human beings is typically the only way to get precious supplies.My PC Specs for comparison CPU- AMD FX(tm)-4130 Quad-Core Processor 3.80GHz GPU- NVIDIA GTX 650 DDR3- 16.00gb Windows 7 64bit Motherboard- M5A78L-M/usb3 Review of Techy Things-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This game has no external DRM (besides steam of coarse)-The game is only 12gb download, which was very weclomed for a full hard drive-When running through the city of Haran I get an average of 45fps, and for my budget computer is extremely good (specs above)Review of Storyline/Gameplay------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------While this game does host it fair share of fetching missions, once I had started the story I just couldn't seem to get enough of this gameplay. The story had its rough parts,  like the final missions being only parkour  but through it all you knew exactly what your goal was and why you were doing it.-As for gameplay and controls think of it as "Dead Island meets Mirror's Edge with a more serious tone."-This is actually one of the first games where I fear for my character's life. Even in horror games like The Evil within I couldn't care less if my character died, but here, I quickly learned to fear the night, as that is when the zombie like to get increasingly faster.-The map is freaking huge, yet easy to travese, and then halfway through the storyline you get another map of slightly lesser size-However as a tradtional "zombie survival" game I think it missed the mark on how available supplies where.Metascore - 75/100Traditional Score - 7.8/10My Rating - 9.2/10End Summary- If you are looking for a fun multiplayer game with some amazing elements of parkour and combat, mixed with the free pvp dlc that game out at launch and a dev team who actually listens to their fanbase to hear the needs of the customers you are in for a sweet treat. If you are looking for another amazing "Last of Us" storyline with sparse pickups, or a true traditional zombie survival I suggest you look elsewhere as this storyline, while is does have some great moments, is mainly comprised of fetching missions, but hey, at least it isn't the cliche roadtrip storyline.

content:
8, 2015
												A great game. Especially the gameplay. Its very fluid, has great parkour, feels wonderful and looks nice, however the balancing is extremely poorly done. Rather then a game with balanced leveling, you feel totally defenceless for the first quarter of the game, then skyrocket to super OP without ever feeling the growth between. The voice acting is lackluster and story is a absolutely TERRIBLE ripoff of far cry 3, however with gameplay as satisfying as this, it is definitely worth is to throw your cash at it. Final Verdict: It feels like a more solidified and fun dead island, with great gameplay, (however short without side missions...) making me come back to it a second time for another playthrough with friends. I suggest either waiting for a slight price drop, and pumping it full of balancing mods once mods are implemented in the game. 8.5/10 (would play again :D)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 2, 2015
												Wasn't too sure how I felt about the game as it starts off on a rough note for me, but past the first few minutes this game more than exceeds my expectations.It's difficult enough without being impossible and it encourages hand to hand action over running and gunning. Even more, it encoruages being familiar with your environment by vaulting over objects - even zombies - and using every single terrain, building and barrier to your advantage.Night play is terrifying the first few times, but you quickly learn to use your feet and manuever around volotile zombies while keeping a healthy fear of them.This game is what Dead Island should have been. It  has a better skill tree, a more complete gameplay experience and characters that aren't total asshats. Each quest feels like its a part of the game instead of just busy work to make you feel like you are getting your moneys worth.The ending is intensly satisfying and while the main storyline itself follows some predicatable turns, it doesn't do it in a way thats so obvious you could plot out the entire story arc in the first fifteen minutes. You can try, but there is a feeling you might get it wrong that makes you want to keep playing.I havent had any performance issues and i'm on a computer with holder hardware, but i do have an Nvidia card. I think most of the launch issues with AMD cards were patched already, but other than that i havent experienced any other glitches. This game is incredibly smooth and there are nice little tidbits the developers leave in for people to find. It does have an assassins creed feel to it, but its so small and in passing that before you can fully explore that thought you have a zombie in your face.I'm already on my second playthrough and i'm noticing little things that make the experience and the world im playing in that much richer and dimensional.If you even semi liked Dead Island, you will really love Dying Light.

content:
er 28, 2016
												     What's interesting about this game is the story and how it evolves throughout the game. It takes place in a fictional city called Harran. Landmarks and people of the city are simply astonishing. Considering the place, it is away from zombie stereotypes, a zombie apocalypse in middle east is a clever and unique idea in my opinion. I was gonna say they could've done the story better but after the Following dlc there was nothing to say. Beautifully connected and the next story was much more interesting and mysterious. I loved how religion placed into the story. I played for the story and probably stayed for the music, it put me into the game and left me suffer. I also loved how the music reflects their environment it was so correct and well done.     Game functions are easy to understand and skill trees are simple and well organized. Weapon crafting is quite fun and creative since using a gun is not a good idea in an environment like this. Co-op is really nice and fun when you have no balls to go out during night. You can continue from your story or your friend's story without any confusion.

content:
er 28, 2015
												ENGLISH:This game is a selective one. If you liked Dead Island you will probably liked this one too. Because it gives you;-Parkour system which also means more freedom while rushing around.-Basic level customization of weapons that you will find it easy to understand and apply.-Day and Night cycle that gives you the true meaning of zombie rush.Graphics are ok. Because when you are on the high settings there isn't really anything to bother you. Since gameplay is so smooth that sometimes you ignore the graphics. Also after updates game's stability boosted , I only countered 1 or 2 crash to desktop with my over 70 hours. I gotta say that I enjoyed both Dead Island and Dying Light. If I had to write bad side of the game that would be ;-Totally cliche characters that we don't even embrace.-Short storyline-Ending feels empty.-Some minor glitches/bugs while freerunning on the narrow passes.Hard mode and "dead is dead" simply makes the game more fun but you lack of vision makes you little bit upset. So I advice you to complete the game on "normal" then go for a real fun at "hard" with "dead is dead" mentality.There is a huge upcoming DLC and I believe it will add much more fun to game.TÜRKÇE:Oyun olması gerektiği şekilde çıksaydı adını Dead Island 2 olarak görebilirdik. Ancak yapımcı anlaşmazlıkları vs. derken oyun yapımcısı olan Polonyalı şirket WB ile anlaşıp kendi oyununu çıkartacağını açıklamıştı. İyi yapmışlar diyebilirim.Oyuna gelirsek Dead Island oyunundan hoşlandıysanız bu oyun hoşunuza gidecektir diye düşünüyorum. Çünkü ;-Çatılara tırmanma vb. gibi bir çok özgürlük sağlıyor. Şehirde istediğiniz gibi dolaşabiliyorsunuz.-Silah yapımı karmaşık değil gayet sade ve iş görür biçimde. Çok komplike şeyler yapmayı hayal etmeyin yani-Gece ve gündüz değişimi oyuna çok farklı bir hava katıyor. Geceleri özellikle zor seviyede inanılmaz çılgın atıyorsunuz.Oyunda çok fazla hata almadım. 70 küsür saatlik süremde 1 veya 2 kere masaüstüne attı yani ben kendi sistemimde test ettiğim kadarı ile gayet akıcı , stabil bir oyun oynadım darısı alanların başına.Kötü taraflarına geleceksek ;-Karakterleri hiçbir şekilde benimseyemedim , çünkü çok klişeler.-Hikaye çok kısa , yan görevleri yapmazsanız bitirmeniz 9 saati bulmuyor. Ancak yan görevlerle 30-40 saat garanti.-Oyun sonu hakkında spoiler vermek istemiyorum ancak hiçbirşey hissetmediğim gerçeğini atlayamam.-Çatılarda , dar geçişlerden geçerken tutunamama vb tarzı sıkıntılar yaşayabiliyorsunuz bu canınızı hayli sıkıyor.Oyunu öncelikle "normal" zorlukta oynamanızı daha sonra "hard" zorlukta oynamanızı öneririm. Çünkü direk "hard" zorlukta başlamak ölüm fermanı gibi birşey çünkü oyunda bazı bilinmesi gereken detaylar var. Zombiler genelde diğer oyunlarla aynı tipte olsada bazı zayıflıkları ve güçtü tarafları var bunların bilinmesi özellikle oyun geceyken çok işinize yarayabilir.Bunun dışında zor modda tek ölüm hakkınız varmış gibi oynarsanız oyunun gerçek hissiyatını alıyorsunuz "gıdım gıdım" yürümek deyimi yerini buluyor özellikle zombilerin nefesini ensenizde hissettiğiniz zaman. İşin komik tarafına gelecek olursak , sabah "laylaylom/gel lan buraya" diyerek kestiğiniz zombiler akşam bir "Kara Murat" edasıyla çatılardan bacalardan zıplayıp hayatı size zehir ediyorlar. Zaten alırda geceye girerseniz dediğim bu lafa gülmemeniz işten bile değil.İyi eğlenceler.

												Great game.  I bought it on release date of the following,  these hours have been put in since then.  An awesome game.  Great to play with current friends or to make new friends.  Decent story and very well optimized currently.  Running @ 60 fps with vsync at 4k resolution on 2 980 ti'sThe main game has a decent story as I said, (better than I expected).  The multiplayer aspect keeps the game fresh for you, in my opinion.  It may also make you a bit braver about going out at night :).  The visuals are stunning.  Especially at Ultra.  I haven't found too many glitches, a few but none that are game breaking.  I have completed the game once and I am currently working on the following and the game has only crashed on me once the entire time.  I don't have the best internet unfortunately, only 20mbps and I have had very few connection issues on the multiplayer side.  Loot system is cool as well as the rpg aspects of the game.  I have had a blast with this game.  It makes you feel bad ♥♥♥ when you start getting good weapons and high level.  Once I got a cross bow I felt like Darrel Dixon from Walking Dead :)  You can too! Hit that buy button!If anyone starting out wants someone to play the game with just Pm me and friend me.

content:
2, 2015
												Dying Light takes a bunch of pages out of the cliche zombie game handbook and refines them to make them feel new. You play as Crane, a employee of the GRE (some goverment organisation i think) to obtain a top secret file that is even disclosed to you. you get droped into Harran which is quarantined off from the world due to a huge infection. After being attacked by a groups of survivors and zombies your saved by two people (one of which dies) and taken to "The Tower" where you are told to meet the boss, instead you talk to a kid in his teens named hasan. At this point you get your first mision and where you learn the mechanics of the game. Hasan has you go through a parkour puzzle and then sends you out on a fetch quest. The gameplay mainly consists of running to a place, avoid zombies, kill zombies, retrieve item, and run back. The game emphasizes using the parkour system to jump on the roofs of building to avoid zombie since most of the zombies can not climb. Most of the time it's better to use a melee weapon since guns make lots of noise and attract zombies. Your starting weapons and horrible and deal no damage and break quickly. It is important to spend the first hour of gameplay seearching for parts and money for weapons that can actually kill things. You can earn skill points by killing zombies, doing tasks, climbing, etc which allows you to unlock new abilitys. You can also craft weapons and items such as medpacks and lockpicks. You also can unlock safehouses by killing the zombies in a certain area and sealing off. Safe houses pretect you from zombies and give you a place to sleep and buy stuff. At nightime the zombies become more aggresive and night hunters come out which are very fast and strong zombies that if they see you will chase you through the city and you have to use traps to avade the hunters. The overall variety of zombies are limited but most of the time I found myself just jumping over and running away from most zombies especially the hammer zombies which deal massive amounts of damage and are hard to kill. The parkour system is a little clucky at times but works fairly well most of the time. The story is pretty intresting especially Rais (the main villan) who had a intresting pesonallity. He is a phyco but not in the traditional way. He will kill his own men for little reason and teases crane throughout the game how crane always takes orders. Other characters like Jade I didn't really like. Crane somehow managed to fall in love with her even though they barley talked to each other. The story overall is pretty good and engaging. The multiplayer is a litttle dull. One the the gamemodes is where one player takes controll of a really overpowered night hunter and the player(s) have to destroy all the nests without loosing all there lives. the survivors can using there UV flashlights to burn the hunter before he latches onto them which burns the hunter and gives the survivors and chance to kill it. The other modes involve killing zombies and collecting loot and other tasks. The level editor is intresiting and it allows you to download user made maps off the workshop to play and adds more replay value. I do not own any of the DLC so I cannot give my opinions on those yet but they don't look that bad. This game is a deffinate overlooked gem of 2015 and may be one of the best games of the first half of 2015. A fun story, good mechanics, and tense gameplay make this a really fun game to play. The only downsides are the repetitive fetch quests, no fast travel, and the abundant use of quick time events. At the 33% off ($40.00) it's 100% worth it and a must have for any zombie game fan. Can't wait to check out the DLC and mess around in the city of Harran some more. 8.8/10

content:
er 12, 2015
 Быстрые ноги зубов не боятсяКратко эту игру можно описать как Dead Island 2. И неудивительно - разработчиком является польская студия Techland, разработавшая в своё время DI. Сходство заметно невооружённым взглядом - живописная расчленёнка, хрупоксть нашего героя (явно имеющего в качестве наставника на базе МакГайвера), симпатичные пейзажи... и вусмерть клишированная история. Нет, я не из тех снобов, которые извергают ядовитую желчь от каждого уже увиденного художественного приёма или сюжетного хода. Просто всё происходящее в основном сюжете мы видели неоднократно. Ну пожалуй за исключением того, что зомби-апокалипсис локален в следствие действий правительства, а не в силу географической привязки/раннего планирования злых корпораций/самого начала бедствия/чего-либо ещё. В  турецкий вымышленный город Харран после внезапной вспышки зомби-вируса, произошедшей как раз перед  Олимпийскими Всемирным Атлетическими Играми где-то в 2014 году по заданию GRE высылают нашего героя - оперативника Кайла Крэйна с заданием найти Кадира Сулеймана, лица, ответственного за обеспечение порядка в городе и изъять у него документы, в которых содержится неполная информация по изготовлению лекарства. Но всё, как известно, идёт наперекосяк с самого начала - герой получает по зубам от каких-то бандитов, а после ещё и обзаводится укусом от зомби. Больше он не Кайл, а теперь он новоиспечённый бегун под номером 31, вынужденный жить от одной порции  Зомбрекса Антизина до другой. Но задание у него остаётся прежним. Сюжет, как я уже отметил выше, не слишком оригинален и не настолько хорошо подан, чтобы на это нельзя было обратить внимание. Но побочные задания на ура вытягивают положение. Тут тебе и поиск мелков и кубиков для детей, тут и убийство некоего тролля, шатающегося по стоянке, и диалоги с человеком, чья мама и мухи не обидит, и доставка алкоголя для дезинфекции при родах и раскрытие заговора рептилиоидов. Боёвка достаточно проста, но ближе к концу игры становится совсем незамысловатой. У врагов здоровье фиксировано, и если поначалу приходится достаточно долго махать гаечным ключом, чтобы зомби наконец-то успокоился (а связываться с тремя-четыремя сразу вообще противопоказано). то уже со второй трети игры оружие становится достаточно мощным, чтобы прорубаться через толпы. Если бы не верная подбородочная нога на пружинке - поначалу было бы ещё хуже. А рукопашные схватки с живыми людьми усложняются ещё больше - увороты и блокирование ударов здесь правило со стороны оппонентов. Так что как и в Dead Island, огнестрел против живых намного эффективнее. Впрочем, меткие выстрелы по головам теперь косят всех рядовых противников. А оружие ближнего боя легко можно улучшить чтобы оно зажигало, било током, травило...Крафт привычный. Разве что теперь не надо искать верстаки - герой сам на коленке скрутит всё, были бы чертежи и нужные припасы. Бесплатно. Для любого холодного оружия. Огнестрельное не модифицируется. Даже сам Кайл при заявлении о том, что "тут у нас есть оружейник, он из любой пукалки гаубицу сделает" отвечает "лучше бы глушитель мог прикрутить". Ремонт тоже быстрый и надёжный. Разве что каждое оружие можно починить лишь конечное количество раз, после чего оно годится лишь в утиль. Звуковое сопровождение... Не оставило особых эмоций. Что музыка, что реплики и т.д. - не слишком запоминается и без очередного техно-трека в какой-то момент вполне можно обойтись. Графика симпатичная. Каких-либо артефактов, огрехов анимации и других проблем не замечал. Порадовало внимание к деталям. Вроде металлических скреп на чиненном-перечиненном топорике или красных глаз у заплаканных девушек. Паркур? Да, ещё одна "основная фишка" игры. Кайл легко скачет по зданиям, прыгает по головам зомби, скользит по зиплайнам, карабкается по стенам, падает (без последствий, если на мусор/машины и с - если на асфальт). Управление лёгкое и если что-то не получается - либо цепляться не за что, либо у вас некоторые проблемы с реакцией. О сетевых режимах, дополнениях и локализации сказать ничего не могу, увы. Не пробовал и после прохождения как-то не тянет. Итог? Всё же рекомендую. История, пусть и избитая, не самая плохая, ночные вылазки подкупают опасностью, жестокие стычки за поставки гуманитарной помощи приедаются далеко не сразу... да и пасхалок со спрятанными уникальными вещами не так мало.

content:
24, 2015
 Innovation in a zombie game? This can't be true! Originally posted by Wikipedia:Dying Light is a zombie apocalypse-themed game set in an open world. Players traverse an expansive urban environment overrun by a vicious epidemic, scavenging the world for supplies and crafting weapons to defend against the growing infected population with a heavy focus on freerunning mechanics, allowing players to perform actions such as climbing ledges, leaping off from edges, sliding, jumping from roofs to roofs and zip-lining.I'll tell you something right away. Dying Light is something you'd never expect from a zombie game: innovation, smooth mechanics, a storyline, tons of tasks, variety and devs who listen to the consumers. So the story... is it really that bad? Not really. The story is not the best thing you could hope for — it's cheesy, it betrays you with a great start... which is bad.  It has replay value, though. The smooth mechanics of the game really save the story, since slicing and bashing zombies and jumping from rooftop to rooftop feels really fluid and it really is a blast. The first half of the main story is promising, but after you get to Old Town, the tasks get quite repetitive and the plot isn't anything special.Overall, Dying Light is a great game, despite its flaws. I couldn't ask for more when it comes to gameplay, weapons and co-op. The only real con is the story — if it was done as well as the game mechanics, this game would be GOTY without a doubt.

content:
6, 2015
												I don't know what to say, honestly.The game is fun, I've spent 43 hours as of this review and I've done nothing more than play around, and I am yet to find things. The game is big, and made for people who like to explore. But if you like to kill, then this is also your game.I'll explain myself here. Dying light can be seen and loved by many points of view. There's a leveling system that will level according to what you do most. There is Agility that specializes on escaping Zombies and climbing, Parkour. Then there's Power, which is the one that specializes in killing zombies and giving you fun and diverse ways to kill them. Storyline:Although I am not yet done with the Dying Light storyline, I'll tell you one thing: If you go straight trying to speedrun through the storyline, you'll end the game quickly, perhaps too quickly too. The game is aimed for you to explore, and enjoy, so if you are not the type to enjoy exploring and looking around looking for the highest place you can climb or how much you can find, how rich you can become, this is not your game. But I will give it to the storyline, I've found myself ignoring countless sidequests and opportunities to explore because I wanted to see what would happen next. Overall, I'd say the Storyline is fun, can hook you on but not something to speedrun through.Exploring:Like I said, this game has an AMAZING exploring system. If you go around and explore you'll find that there are collectibles for you to find, and chances are on first look you're not gonna find them all. There are three sorts of things you can find around the world. Zombie Statues, Flags and Notes. That is all I am gonna say. There are 30 Flags, like 100 Zombie statues and 67 notes. If you are the type to play this game and find everything and enjoy everything. You will find yourself enjoying this game to the maximum. Because there is a lot to explore and exploring is rewarded. Easter eggs can be found and the game will last a lot longer.Fighting:Although I will say, I died a LOT on this game, most of it was not because the Zombies took the upper hand and killed me. Zombies will seem threatening and even a bit scary at the early stages of the game. Where it takes you 5 hits to kill them and it is really satisfying to kill your first Zombie, your first 10, and soon your first 100. Zombies are fun to kill, even a bit relaxing after a while and if you get overwhelmed, even a bit hard to beat. There are many types of Zombies, I will not get into detail with them because that is for you to find out, but personally, I am satisfied with the fighting on this game. The Zombies don't follow Ragdoll physics, so if you kill one by kicking them off a cliff, they will look almost human falling off a cliff.Parkour:The Parkour in this game is very fun, at first a bit confusing but really fun in general. You will be able to find the highest place you can climb to and even find yourself just parkouring out of the actual questline or sidequest you were doing. Some fun things about Parkour is that there are some things you can find in some houses that you would not have found had you not gone ontop of a house or even a building. Overall, there is not much to say about parkour more than it's fast, exciting, and I would definitely say it is fun, although I found myself raging because I would die from fall distance, and whatnot but that's because I'm stubborn.Co-op:Co-op adds a LOT to this game. I found myself constantly running off from my partner just to see what I could find, and eventually both of us meeting somewhere and exchanging what it is that we found. Ranging from Weapons that perhaps he liked the bat and I liked the Cleaver, or anything, really. Co-op adds a different element to this game, that allows you to survive a Zombie Apocalypse with a friend, not alone. I would definitely reccomend it.Customization:Although this game is lacking whether I can be a female Runner or not, I would say it was quite disapointing. My Co-op friend also being Kyle Crane kind of killed the entire fun of two survivors and it made it seem more like that was just my twin running around. Outfits are pretty, I will admit that but they are not the maximum customization I would have wanted from this game. Overall, a bit disappointed.Overall:Dying Light is a game that can reach out to a lot of people. I, for one adore every aspect of the game whether it is getting Airdrops to rank up on Survival. Parkouring and jumping over Zombies to see if maybe I can find another note, another flag or another Zombie Statue or to see just what else I can discover. And also the fighting on the game that can be extremely satisfying with the slow motion, succeeding on the game making me feel indeed as a Hunter at Day and Prey at Night. I'll reccomend this game to any person. Even if it's just to do the storyline, it is a lot of fun. My rating for this game would be 9/10.

												Very good coop game, no spoilers in that review.7/10 And you'll see why I think so here : The pros : Coop with 4 people, Lots of things to do. Melee weapons are the best, really gory and fun. Many kinds of infected. From the basic slow one, to the very fast and deadly ones. You cannot exchange money between your fellow players. You can though drop a weapon on the floor to give it. A lot of missions can get repetitive. If you stay on the campaing, it is less boring for singleplayer play, but it is very boring if you decide to do everything. Don't expect to play with guns much. Yeah there are some guns but they the game really don't make them feel right for a FPS genre. There are mods you can install to correct that I suppose.All and all, 7/10.

content:
30
												Where do I start. First off, this is one of the best games I have ever played. It's like Dead Island, except better in every possible way. Graphics are great, facial animations are great, and just overall a great atmostphere. You really feel as if you are actually in the game, it pulls you in and doesn't let go.        The parkour aspect is top notch. It feels genuine, and not like some arcadey junk. Running across rooftops, climbing fences, and running away from volatiles at night really gets your blood going.         Combat system is great. Most of the weapons you will use are melee weapons (one handed and two handed), but there are also guns (pistols, assault rifles, shotguns, smgs), a bow with different arrow types and a crossbow thrown into the mix once you start the following. There are a ton of collectible blueprints scattered around the map, and some you can get from completing missions, that you can use to enhance your melee weapon with different effects like Toxic, Electric, Fire, and Impact. More advanced blueprints let you put two effects on one weapon. It is so damn staisfying chopping off heads with a machete and bashing in zombie skulls with a sledgehammer.          The story is alright, not going to dive into any spoilers, but it does its job in keeping everything flowing smoothly. I have completed the main story twice now, and all of the side quests as well.          You get two different maps in the base game, Slums and Old Town, that I think are very detailed and do a good job of rewarding exploration. Each one has a very different feel to it, and that helps add to the overall atmostphere of the game.          This is one of the few games where I have found/completed most of the easter eggs, and collected most if not all of the developer blueprints. No other game has made me want to come back and throughly collect and explore as much as Dying Light. I love going around and exploring every little nook and cranny, just to make sure there's nothing that I missed. The biggest thing I have accomplished is grinding for about 12 hours or so, getting around 9k disater relief packages to reach max legend level at 250. I don't believe any other game will pull me back in as much as this one.           To sum it up, Dying Light is one of the best games I have and I think I will ever play. Everything from the graphics, the animations, the combat, the parkour and the story, feels very very solid and well done. And as much fun as it is to play it alone, playing with your friends is an absolute blast. Techland nailed this one. 10/10

												Great single/co-op narrative driven open world game. The world isn't as big as I'd like since I've been spoiled by the likes of DayZ scale maps but it's still quite enough to run around in and not get bored with the scenery.Graphics - AAA studio quality, 9/10 - 10/10 depending on how picky you are, the ambiance is definitely there.Atmosphere - Immersion is the game here and Dying Light does it particularly well. Enjoy all the free-roaming parkour action you can han handle while being chased by various types of flesh eating zombies....works for me.Story - So far fairly typical but it's got layers, can't really say much without ruining it but it's more than just skin deep.Pvp - Dunno, I turned off invasions and stuff because I'm playing it for story/co-op experience, look elsewhere for a pvp review.Co-op - Works great, play with friends in seconds, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥ day 1 launch, everything runs smoooooothe.Overall - Engaging, beautiful, dangerous, fun. Personal score 9/10 (only because I'm not done with the story all the way, the score could go up or down but it's a solid 8 on anyones scale)ENJOY!!!Worth 60 if you like dead island mixed with mirrors edge. If you didn't like Dead Island then you might not want to purchase until it's cheaper.

content:
ry 2, 2015
												Wasn't too sure how I felt about the game as it starts off on a rough note for me, but past the first few minutes this game more than exceeds my expectations.It's difficult enough without being impossible and it encourages hand to hand action over running and gunning. Even more, it encoruages being familiar with your environment by vaulting over objects - even zombies - and using every single terrain, building and barrier to your advantage.Night play is terrifying the first few times, but you quickly learn to use your feet and manuever around volotile zombies while keeping a healthy fear of them.This game is what Dead Island should have been. It  has a better skill tree, a more complete gameplay experience and characters that aren't total asshats. Each quest feels like its a part of the game instead of just busy work to make you feel like you are getting your moneys worth.The ending is intensly satisfying and while the main storyline itself follows some predicatable turns, it doesn't do it in a way thats so obvious you could plot out the entire story arc in the first fifteen minutes. You can try, but there is a feeling you might get it wrong that makes you want to keep playing.I havent had any performance issues and i'm on a computer with holder hardware, but i do have an Nvidia card. I think most of the launch issues with AMD cards were patched already, but other than that i havent experienced any other glitches. This game is incredibly smooth and there are nice little tidbits the developers leave in for people to find. It does have an assassins creed feel to it, but its so small and in passing that before you can fully explore that thought you have a zombie in your face.I'm already on my second playthrough and i'm noticing little things that make the experience and the world im playing in that much richer and dimensional.If you even semi liked Dead Island, you will really love Dying Light.

er 9, 2015
												Despite some minor content bugs, worth the entry fee if the subject matter appeals to you. The smooth parkour controls and excellent online coop seal the deal on the hybrid successor to Dead Island which cleverly and unapologetically marries numerous compatible action/survival features from many other AAA games to create an enjoyable chimera whose merits far outweigh its shortcomings.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I thought since I had finally beaten this game that I'd delete my old review that I made the day this game launched. It was less of a review and more of a "Don't play this if you have AMD" PSA. If you'd like to read it, I kept a screenshot here- http://gyazo.com/efe939cdf154cd75f3ce66bfa1c1d358However the issues mentioned there were MOSTLY fixed. They never really bothered fixing crossfire glitches or properly optimizing the game to AMD, but they've at least made it playable. Being that I pre-ordered I still feel kind of betrayed that they'd treat my system like garbage just cause I have AMD GPUs, but I'd like to toss that all aside for now and talk about the game itself will all technical issues aside.+This game's graphics are beautiful. I can finally crank everything up to high except view distance due to the optimization Techland HAS done, and it looks amazing. My only complaint is there's too many nonsensical particles floating around...everywhere. Not a big deal, just an immersion-breaker sometimes.+The best parkour system I have ever seen in any game. Makes Mirrors Edge look like a protoype.+The combat is very fun and very responsive. You can feel the weight of two-handed weapons and every gadget you can craft can be used tactically to your advantage or disadvantage in the midst of combat.+The crafting system is even better than in Dead Island. From upgrading your weapons with elemental abilities to adding "mods" to them to simply buff the stats they already have. You can also craft a number of tools and gadgets to help you such as flares, firecrackers, night-vision enhancing boosters, and grenades to name a few.+The sounds are great. From the running, to the fires, to the zombie cries, to the screamers, to the grunts of pain and fear your character has. They are very immersive.+MODS! Modding community! What does that mean? EXTENDED LIFESPAN! The mods allow creators to add new scenarios to the game, create stories of their own. This has already extended the lifespan of the game and will continue to do so and long as the community keeps producing quality mods.+The drop in and drop out co-op mode we all know from dead island is done just as well here as it has been done before. The connection is always stable and it is a blast to play this game with a friend.+/-Multiplayer is actually quite fun. You play as a "hunter" and invade the games of players (Invade 1 lone player or a full group of 4!), trying to acquire 10 kills before they can destroy 5 of your hives. Unfortunately however I have seen people who when invaded crank on some trainers/hacks so that they can always see you through objects at any distance, which ruins the experience sometimes. You can tell if its a hacker if you're having a staring contest through 10 buildings for about a minute.+/- The game doesn't have too much replayability story-wise. But if you like the gameplay a lot like I do, the game definitely warants a New Game Plus playthrough on Hard Mode just to face the challenge.-The characters however are sub-par. Each has little to no character development and I never quite felt attached to any of these characters by the end of my experience. ESPECIALLY in scenes of death that you could tell were supposed to be "meaningful" I was just like....ok. You didn't develop that character at all, stop pretending you did please. Every one of these characters are cliche and predictable at that, they've been done a million times before.-The story is the most predictable, most cliche, and least interesting story I've ever played in a AAA title. Techland made this game since they didn't want to make another "comedic" Dead Island game. Looks like their "comedy" is the only thing that ever made their stories interesting to begin with. Because Dying Light's story is "Just another sitcom" in a sea of sitcoms when you're already watching Friends.Now for the final verdict. Taking into account everything stated above, including the CURRENT technical state of the game, I'd give this game an 8.5/10. I really wanted to push for a 9/10 here but the game just doesn't earn it. It's still very unoptimized for AMD systems. Old crossfire bugs that they announced were being fixed shortly after release are still existent. That and the characters and story are so poorly done the game wasn't interesting in any other aspect but the combat, and that's not really what RPGs are supposed to be rembered for. Maybe in time they'll fix the optimization issues and I will update my review if they do, but until then I can still safely recommend this game to just about everyone. However if you do use AMD, do note you will NOT get the full power of your GPUs. CPUs work fine, but your GPUs are not optimized for this game.

content:
y 27, 2015
												This game surpassed my expectations both positively and negatively. As amazingly fun and satisfying as it is, it is also one of the most rage inducing games I have ever played recentlyPros: Things I loved-Satisfying sound effects (oohh glorious gore)-Intelligent Human AI, for example if you pull out a gun they will surrender if they have only melee weapons. However, if they have strength in numbers they will not give in, they will simply keep their distance and throw knives and ♥♥♥♥ at you from cover and roof tops-Great parkour mechanics, not clunky or faulty in the slightest-A truly immersive story, it not only has emotion but suspense as well as a dynamic protagonist as well.-Weapon customization and rarity is very balanced-Night time is challenging, you truly are the prey at night. Fighting back against Night Virals is almost useless. Night is very dramatic, anxiety inducing, horrific, and exhillirating. But they still sweeten the pot with double XP if you're up to the challenge after dark.-Wonderful and properly implemented environmental killsCons: Now for the rage inducing part-Despite the wonderful AI for humans. They are extremely overpowered. Not only are they pretty much unaffected by kicks (one of your most useful abilities), they also seem to have superhuman reflexes and health as well. Also they tend to throw knives with almost 100% accuracy, seemingly from angles that not even Captain America himself could throw ♥♥♥♥ from and hit his (moving) target.-Zombies grapple you every five seconds, and medkits are rare. Though they can be quickly countered it happens way too often. However it is something you must be smart about as this game is not about plunging through hordes of infected. It encourages you to keep your distance however the main issue is it's used a little too frequently, and it is also a very clunky mechanic. If a zombie attempts to grapple you, kicking it a split second too late (even if the kick lands successfully) the hitboxes be like "Nah he got you first." The main dodge and throw thing you do is ineffective because of this. 60% of the time it will register the zombie grappling you regardless if you press the series of buttons first.-The game tends to kick you while you're down a lot. You lose XP when you die, and if you're broke and have no equipment it adds insult to injury with constant death as well. A lot of the game depends on how well equipped you are, and if you're not well equipped enough not only do you die a lot, it's very hard to climb out of that pit of chronic death once you're already ♥♥♥♥ed as it is, it's not very helpful when you're losing XP non stop at the same time. Especially at night.-The game tends to bs you into instant death a lot. It's very aggravating especially the fact that every flammable object tends to explode for seemingly no reason a lot of the time.Summary: Great game, the combat mechanics need improvement for specific things. 8.5/10

content:
er 12, 2016
												Dying Light is an absolute masterpiece when it comes to zombie games. As it is indeed THE zombie game. It combines one of the best free-running mechanics I've ever seen with an incredibly detailed map and rather well built. Which adds more to the experience.At the start you begin with nothing and feel naked, but as you progress this fear dissipitates and another sets in, which is the volatiles and the hunters.The way the game keeps you on your toes is incredible and the story even if a bit cliche keeps it all together. Having experienced both the dying light and the following and still getting a kick out of the game with new game(+) mode where you can keep all your stuff and perks. Other than that the game is extremely well optimized and even amongst the chaos, the blood, the massacre and the running you'll find yourself stopping on top of a building to just gaze on the map. Verdict : Dying Light is hands down THE zombie AND the best parkour game I have ever played and I recommend it to anyone who wants something like the undead genre to be refreshed through a solid campaign, a good multiplayer which offers competition as well as rewards and an overall excellent experience.Absolutely a 10/10!!!

												Is the game perfect? No, but no game is.Is it going to be fun for everyone? Not if they have a weak computer or just don't enjoy the genre.Have I played any games that do open world zombie survival better? Absolutly not, this is by far the best game of its type.8.5/10 Half a point off for minor technical issues (typical NV Gameworks nonsense, etc)Half a point off for nonsense goofball weapons that don't really fit in with the rest of the game (duct tape a knife to another knife and then duct tape that to a molotov coctail and somehow you have a sword with improved durability, damage, and lights enemies on fire... wtf?) and other immersion quirks.Half a point off for some pretty strictly pay-to-win DLCs (Weapons that beat anything you can get otherwise in the game, and are avaliable from the very start if you buy the DLCs).

												It's a typical Technland product, that's for sure, but it was also to be expected that there will be issues (performance optimizations).So far however that is my only negative aspect. I already liked the Dead Islands and Dying light improves every aspect (controlls, story, characters, gameplay, overall size). It's by far not perfect, but in my opinion the best zombie game right now. Not too arcady and not too much realism simulator either.Also, the combination of Dead Island and Mirrors Edge feels like a natural fusion and pretty much all I wished for. It always hurts in fps games, that even small obstacles stop you movement and the constant feeling "in real live getting up there wouldn't be an issue at all. (There are still places and borders you can't go around, but those are at a minimum and don't affect the gamplay too much)There are a lot of people that have an issue with decaying weapons, but honestly, there are more than enough lying around, and you can repair your weapons and with skills you can delay the decay.

												Parkour, Zombies and Diablo-esque weapons. An interesting mix with a dark shades of grey storyline. Although there is a clear underdog/good-guy in the game it's not a great part of the storyline. I'd much prefer to have more agency as the player. For instance in the end scene I specifically made sure I had a rifle and a pistol but becaue of the QTE nature of the finale I did not get to use them. Overall it is an addictive game. The mobility and the initial survival aspects pull you in. Recommended.

content:
y 27
												Dying Light is an open world zombie apocalypse survival game set in a large city for you to explore, loot, kill and scavenge.Being open world you shouldn’t run out of places to roam and explore, even more so coupled with the fact you can climb pretty much any ledge you see, this will make up a large portion of your interaction with the game world, coming back down again can seem absurd at times as you jump into piles of trash bags or simply do a forward roll once you come to the ground off a 4 story building, map sizes are fairly large which there are two of in the base game. While exploring the open world you’ll discover many crates and vans to test out your lockpicking skills in the pursuit of finding some higher level weapon which will slice through zombies ever so more easily (but no less satisfying), or some valuable medkit crafting supplies, if you find yourself running out of lockpicks you can craft your own, just look around looting the corpses of slain zombies or search cupboards and baskets for the crafting materials. Combat is incredibly fun although somewhat repetitive, swing at a neck to decapitate with a sharp sword or aim a baseball bat to a limb and break it - a satisfying crunch will follow.  Drop kicking is by far the funniest thing to do especially on roof tops, sending a zombie off to the street below seems to never get old.  But the combat system isn't without its flaws because things get buggy once online with what seem to be syncing issues (game struggles to decide whether it was you or a friend who’s attack hit first).There’s a decent amount of weapons at your disposal which come in the usual categories such as, sharp, blunt, 1 handed, 2 handed, throwing and firearms, the latter being utter crap in my opinion. They are upgradeable and moddable which is something I normally shy away from now because weapons have a durability and can not be repaired indefinitely so after some prolonged use they’ll be rendered useless.The main story and characters are probably this game's weak points as I never really cared as to what I was trying to achieve or who for so I found myself running from one marker to the next, there are many side quests to deviate from the main story keeping you busy.Teaming up with a maximum of 3 friends for online co-op is possibly the game's best feature and where I’ve had the most fun, dropping in and out of games is also very easy to do.Alternatively become a zombie, drop into someone else's game and hunt them down. The lighting in Dying Light is also another great asset to this game and even more so at night, the way buildings are lit up or the flashes from a thunder storm make for a somewhat believably realistic atmosphere, but don’t hang around too long as things get more challenging once the sun is down, zombies are far more aggressive and they’ll be accompanied by stranger nocturnal creatures. Most of the music in this game is brilliant and really has echos similar to the movies of the 70’s and 80’s giving that very eerie vibe.If you are a fan of all things zombie but feel it's an overused genre in recent years I'd still recommend Dying Light.

content:
23, 2015
												Dying Light presents a great example of the zombie genre’s coming of age. Serious, impactful and brutal, but still suffering from a few lingering issues that seem to plague the entire concept of the undead in interactive entertainment. Poorly directed narrative with little motivation beyond getting from point A to B, a lot of stereotypical NPCs, and a traditionally out-dated damsel-in-distress plot-point are among the most glaring of pitfalls the game suffers, but taken as a whole package, it stands high above most other zombie games and declares, “I am different. I am fun. I am Dying Light!”. And you know what? It is different. With it’s speed orientated focus on survival and it’s visceral and punishing combat, it differentiates itself from even it’s closest kin, the Dead Island franchise, which frankly feels like a proof of concept for Dying Light by comparison. It is fun. With a great level of challenge, a huge array of weaponry and moves, more Easter eggs than the upcoming Christian holiday, and loads of pop culture references, it is fun. And, well, it is Dying Light. Need I say more? 8.9/10For full review, read my article over at http://shoddypixels.com/dying-light-review/

content:
, 2015
												Very good coop game, no spoilers in that review.7/10 And you'll see why I think so here : The pros : Coop with 4 people, Lots of things to do. Melee weapons are the best, really gory and fun. Many kinds of infected. From the basic slow one, to the very fast and deadly ones. You can collect stuff, collect weapons, buy weapons, buy stuff to make more stuff. Story is very good. Connexion is very playable. I have seen very few glitches, some are funny. You have a bunch of very interresting skills (like the grappling hook) that transforms the game and make it even better.The cons : the end mission forces you to play singleplayer, don't expect to bring your friends there. You cannot exchange money between your fellow players. You can though drop a weapon on the floor to give it. A lot of missions can get repetitive. If you stay on the campaing, it is less boring for singleplayer play, but it is very boring if you decide to do everything. Don't expect to play with guns much. Yeah there are some guns but they the game really don't make them feel right for a FPS genre. There are mods you can install to correct that I suppose.All and all, 7/10.

I would say its the best zombie game to this date , well it has some Dead Island feel to it and fantastic Mirror's Edge parkour . Graphics are very good but for amd users there used to be some problems , but nvidia is working perfectly.Gameplay - 8.7/10 Its very good but could use some inprovement.Story - Shortly explaned you are Kyle Crane (ofc you have to be some military dude or smthing like that) You have a mission to i guess scout the Harran/Slums/Old Town to see what is happened when the infection broke ... You get into some infected place and you got bitten and i could say story is very decent for a i can say a zombie game .Parkour - It is very great almost like in mirror's edge but when u get the grappling hook its a bit well it doesnt serve a purpose since you can grapple everywhere u can but lets say that u like parkouring.I like that game doesnt really crash and it has stable 60 fps at the highest graphics and settings.What i dont like that surviving is REALLY REALLY hard in the beggining and in the night ... At the night time like the game completely changes its very hard and i wouldnt reccomend u to go in the night . Problem is that the weapons become unusuable and surviving is not difficult at the like end of the game or etc cause you have legendary weapons , ALL SKILLS and a bunch of medkit's , molotov's other stuff and lets face it you have so much healt you will not use it ... But i like about the game it is FUN co-op is very good and be the zombie mode is at first challenging anad if you play it you can just laught at normal people.The Following - Now you get it with the game , but i bought it cause I bought the game early but thats not a problem .Why should you buy the following - New story , new effects , new weapons (crossbow , firearms etc). AND THE BUGGY c: Its very fun to drive around while smashing zombies . I would recommend this game to everyone actually i really enjoyed it , If you have friends to play with its even better because co-op is very fun ...Special Infected - There is a lot of em (they are bosses and hard at first ) but when u get the legendary weapons its easy to beat them but they are fun .Infected - They are smarter than in other games (dead island,dead rising). They actually know parkour . In the start of the game with the weapons u get (rusty pipes, wood planks) its hard to kill them. But with the korek machete or just other fire arms even legendary weapons its easy . But very fun . Volatiles are your nightmare (litteraly) . Dont get close to their nests. I love about the game you can just explore stuff and drive around in your buggy c: Rating 9/10 .

content:
y 27
												Dying Light is an open world zombie apocalypse survival game set in a large city for you to explore, loot, kill and scavenge.Being open world you shouldn’t run out of places to roam and explore, even more so coupled with the fact you can climb pretty much any ledge you see, this will make up a large portion of your interaction with the game world, coming back down again can seem absurd at times as you jump into piles of trash bags or simply do a forward roll once you come to the ground off a 4 story building, map sizes are fairly large which there are two of in the base game. While exploring the open world you’ll discover many crates and vans to test out your lockpicking skills in the pursuit of finding some higher level weapon which will slice through zombies ever so more easily (but no less satisfying), or some valuable medkit crafting supplies, if you find yourself running out of lockpicks you can craft your own, just look around looting the corpses of slain zombies or search cupboards and baskets for the crafting materials. Combat is incredibly fun although somewhat repetitive, swing at a neck to decapitate with a sharp sword or aim a baseball bat to a limb and break it - a satisfying crunch will follow.  Drop kicking is by far the funniest thing to do especially on roof tops, sending a zombie off to the street below seems to never get old.  But the combat system isn't without its flaws because things get buggy once online with what seem to be syncing issues (game struggles to decide whether it was you or a friend who’s attack hit first).There’s a decent amount of weapons at your disposal which come in the usual categories such as, sharp, blunt, 1 handed, 2 handed, throwing and firearms, the latter being utter crap in my opinion. They are upgradeable and moddable which is something I normally shy away from now because weapons have a durability and can not be repaired indefinitely so after some prolonged use they’ll be rendered useless.The main story and characters are probably this game's weak points as I never really cared as to what I was trying to achieve or who for so I found myself running from one marker to the next, there are many side quests to deviate from the main story keeping you busy.Teaming up with a maximum of 3 friends for online co-op is possibly the game's best feature and where I’ve had the most fun, dropping in and out of games is also very easy to do.Alternatively become a zombie, drop into someone else's game and hunt them down. The lighting in Dying Light is also another great asset to this game and even more so at night, the way buildings are lit up or the flashes from a thunder storm make for a somewhat believably realistic atmosphere, but don’t hang around too long as things get more challenging once the sun is down, zombies are far more aggressive and they’ll be accompanied by stranger nocturnal creatures. Most of the music in this game is brilliant and really has echos similar to the movies of the 70’s and 80’s giving that very eerie vibe.If you are a fan of all things zombie but feel it's an overused genre in recent years I'd still recommend Dying Light.

content:
14, 2015
												Before I get into what I do and don't like about the game, I should mention that I have an Alienware AMD machine. Before purchasing the game I read reviews and articles about how this game wasn't optimized for AMD machines. I decided to bite the bullet anyways because one can only watch so many gameplays and eventually want to play for themselves. This game seemed awesome from the youtube videos and despite having read about the AMD vs Nvidia discussions I sold some CS GO skins so as to be able to get it.At first the game is quite grainy and seemed to have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fps. I toyed around with the video settings and it wasn't until I switched it to Best Performance setting that I was even able to move my mouse around without the graphics stuttering. I did more reading and I found a handy program called Process Lasso which I highly recommend. Obviusly read about it and what it does before doing anything that can potentially ♥♥♥♥ up your machine. I highly suggest reading up on it herehttps://bitsum.com/processlasso/. I digress. Once I figured out my problem was I no longer felt duped and was ready to move on with completing missions while avoiding harassment from the undead. Things I liked:-Its reminiscent of Mirror's Edge-The skill tree is less like that of Dead Island and more like Borderlands/Borderlands 2. The skills you spend your points on will most likely make you either or. On my part I seem to be leaning towards having better defensive skills rather than combative.-Graphics are amazing and it played on my fear of heights; I found myself screaming "Jump ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, JUMP!" while trying to outrun a zombie that was chasing after me. The game is immersive to the point that when I do jump I feel like I'm on the tower of terror everytime I land; you know that feeling that you get when your insides seem to wanna come out?-I like the storyline.Things I didn't like:-Maybe its because I'm still trying to get used to it, or maybe it's because I'm still trying out which one I prefer; my XBOX controller of the mouse and keypad, but I feel that the controls could be a bit more seamless. Actions that need to happen in sequence are harder (for me) to execute because the bindings are physically too far apart. -It might be too scary to play by yourself during the nighttime mode. The zombies do not ♥♥♥♥ around when the lights go out.-Be the Zombie Mode seems more of an interruption than an enhancement.
